title: Royal British Legion unveils 20ft high poppy installation
story: A 20ft installation has been erected featuring messages written by soldiers from World War One woven into strands which point towards 14 other memorials around the country. Pictured is Barbara Weatherill, who served in the Royal Artillery during the Second World WarMilitary personnel have paid their respects to those who have fallen in service to their country at the launch of the Poppy Appeal in Greenwich today           The Legion said the memorial, pictured, aimed to highlight how 'the legacy of the First World War is woven through the fabric of the nation, often in unexpected places'          At the top of the installation is a huge poppy, uniting all the displays around the UK under the symbol of the LegionThe Legion said it aimed to highlight how 'the legacy of the First World War is woven through the fabric of the nation, often in unexpected places'. The messages written on the threads and the locations have been chosen to acknowledge the wide range of contributions from across the First World War generation.The Royal British Legion's Director of Fundraising, Claire Rowcliffe said: 'During the Poppy Appeal 2018 and as we mark the end of the First World War centenary in this historic year, we are calling on the nation to say 'Thank You' to the First World War generation, not only the British Armed Forces, but those who fought alongside them from today's Commonwealth, the countless men, women and children who played their part of the home front and the pioneers and artists who have left long lasting legacies.'You are the epitome of stupid': Student rep sparks outrage...Ex British Army major who asked his MP to hand his service...STEPHEN GLOVER: What topsy-turvy morality when our old...Share this article'The work of the Legion is as relevant and vital today as it was in the aftermath of the First World War when the charity was founded. 'The donation for your poppy will help the Legion support today's Armed Forces community through hardships, injury and bereavements.           The threads of the memorial, pictured, point to various significant locations around the country, including Preston's Deepdale Stadium, the Big Pit Museum in Wales and the Library of Birmingham          Each thread, pictured, has a quote or message from someone associated with The Great War such as poet Wilfred Owen or military personnel  The new memorial has been erected as the Legion targets its highest ever appeal total of £50million'Generations of the Armed Forces have continued to serve and sacrifice since the First World War, and we recognise and thank them all for their unique contribution.'This Poppy Appeal we have set our highest ever target at £50 million. The Legion's work is entirely dependent on the public's generous support – so please wear your poppy with pride and dig deep, knowing that you are supporting our Armed Forces community.'The Legion uses donations to offer life-long support to the Armed Forces community including providing crisis grants, researching the changing impact of blast injuries on the body, lobbying the government on issues that affect our Armed Forces community, specialist dementia care, sport and art based recovery programmes and advising on benefits and money problems.You can donate to the Poppy Appeal here. The 14 partner locations around the UK are as follows:   The Response Memorial, Newcastle (Until 29 October) One memorial has been set up at the pre-existing The Response monument in Newcastle to recognise how workers left their jobs in industry to go to war.The 5th Northumberland Fusiliers, now known as the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers, is featured in the monument to represent how tightknit joined up to fight together.It depicts how men and boys left their families and loved ones behind to go fight while women remained stoically at home to ensure daily life carried on as normal.The message: 'We are going back to where we came from, the Land of Hell, for it's nothing no more than Hell on Earth' - Bill (Soldier of the Great War, surname and regiment unknown)           One location linked up with the Greenwich display is The Response memorial in Newcastle, pictured, which pays tribute to the city's workers who left their industrial jobs to join the Armed Forces          Wreaths are regularly laid at the foot of the monument, pictured, which features the The 5th Northumberland Fusiliers, now known as the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers  Training Trenches, RAF Halton, Aylesbury (Until 29 October) Another display is at RAF Halton in Aylesbury, once part of the Rothschild Estate, who gave up the land to help train soldiers to prepare for battle on the Western Front.By 1916 more than 20,000 troops were on site at any one time, practicing drills in trenches and honing their skills and discipline.   The following year Halton became the home of technical training for the Royal Flying Corps. When, in 1918 the Royal Air Force was formed, RAF Halton then became the home of the new RAF Apprenticeship Scheme.The message: 'Thank You to the Armed forces of the First World War who helped shape our world.'           RAF Halton in Aylesbury was also picked because it was a training ground for troops heading to the Western Front, with trenches, pictured, dug out to help new recruits and veterans alike prepare for battle          The base would train 20,000 soldiers at one time by 1916, and a year later it became a technical training ground for the Royal Flying Corps, which would go on to become the RAF  The Big Pit National Coal Museum, Blaenavon (Until 29 October)The Big Pit National Coal Museum in Blaenavon, Wales, has also been chosen to host a partner memorial after it saw its workforce decimated by the war, which led to women and children picking up the workload.The site, now dedicated to the preservation of the heritage of Welsh coal mining, represents one of the many working pits across the coalfields of Great Britain that fuelled a nation engaged in a scale of industrialised war never before seen. The skills of the miners were repurposed in the dark, silent battle underneath no man's land with men like Capt Arthur Edwards pioneering this tactic to break the stalemate, winning a Military Cross in the process.The message: 'Cos we'd been miners, biggest part of the battalion or the ision were miners, the majority' - Irving Jones, Welsh Regiment           The Big Pit Museum in Blaenavon, Wales, pictured, also forms one of the 14 partner locations to celebrate the work women and children did in the mines to keep the country's industry afloat while male workers went away to war          Miners were able to adapt skills they used to navigate their work underground to their advantage in the trenches. Pictures is the red thread outside the Welsh mine-turned-museum          The site in Blaenavon, pictured, is now dedicated to preserving the history of the mining industry and its contribution to Wales  Ballyclare Football Club, County Antrim (Until 29 October)Ballyclare Football Club in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, was chosen because the club was first created in 1919 as Ballyclare Comrades, formed by returning soldiers who missed the sense of camaraderie that trench warfare had created among them.It was formed by men of C Company, 12th Royal Irish Rifles (now Royal Irish Regiment) who found football, the 'soldiers' game', to be the perfect way to reconnect.  The Ballycare Comrades FC is still going strong and will celebrate their centenary next year.The Message: 'Would you believe it, by mutual consent our Battalion and the Germans opposite had a little armistice and didn't fire a shot all day' - Pvt Marmaduke Walkinton on the Christmas truce           The thread pictured at Ballyclere Football Club in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by a returning regiment of soldiers who missed the camaraderie formed in the trenches  No.10 Downing Street, London (Not available to visit) Elsewhere in London, 10 Downing Street has been chosen to host a memorial to mark former prime minister David Lloyd George announcing the Armistice to jubilant crowds in November 1918Speaking from the doorstep on November 11, he said: 'I am glad to tell you that the war will be over by 11 o'clock today.'The people of this country and our allies, the Dominions and of India, have won a great victory for humanity. The sons and daughters of the people have done it. They have won this hour of gladness, and the whole country has done its duty.'A Legion spokesman added: 'It is this hour of gladness of which Lloyd George spoke on the steps of Number 10 Downing Street which is embodied in the 'Thank You' movement, and the echo of his words 'The sons and daughters of the people have done it'.'The message: 'Thank You to the First World War Generation that served, sacrificed and changed our world'           10 Downing Street, pictured, has been chosen as one of the partner locations to mark then prime minister David Lloyd George announcing the end of the war in 1918          Speaking from the doorstep on November 11, 1918, Mr Lloyd George said: 'The people of this country and our allies, the Dominions and of India, have won a great victory for humanity'  Women's Land Army Tribute, National Memorial Arboretum, Staffordshire (Until 29 October) To recognise the role women have played in the services, a display has been created at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire, honouring the 'Land Girls' who worked on farms to plant and harvest crops and ensure the continued supply of dairy produce.With their uniform of green ties and jumpers and brown felt slouch hats, they worked from dawn to dusk each day, milking cows, digging ditches, sowing seeds and harvesting crops. When women became a crucial part of the nation's workforce during the war they stepped closer to the right to vote which they were given in 1918. The message: 'And it came for his man to come back from leave and then he said 'Oh, he'd - rather keep the girl driver' - Dolly Shepherd, Women's Army Corps driver           The memorial at National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire recognises the role women had as 'Land Girls' during past conflicts, making sure the agricultural industry continued to prosper  Deepdale Stadium, Preston (Until 29 October) Preston North End's Deepdale Stadium was picked to host a memorial because it was the location of a special football match on Christmas Day, 1917.It was played between women who worked at munitions factory Dick, Kerr &amp Co to raise money for wounded soldiers being treated at the town's hospital.The match generated £600, which would be closer to £40,000 converted to today's moneyThe Message: 'Not only WRNS, but the other two services, also, pioneered the beginning of votes for women and freedom for women more' - Beatrice Browne, typist with the Women's Royal Naval Service           Preston North End's Deepdale Stadium, pictured, was also chosen for the Appeal because it was the site of a charity football match in 1917 between women's teams who raised cash to help treat wounded soldiers          The memorial in Preston, pictured, pays tribute to the working women of the town who raised the equivalent of £40,000 in support of the wounded soldiers in hospital  The Royal Pavilion, Brighton (Until 25 October) The Royal Pavilion in Brighton is also proudly hosting a display to recognise the part the wider British Empire played in the First World War.Indian soldiers wounded in battle were taken to a hospital in the pavilion between 1914 and 1916, including Muslims, Sikhs and Hindus.They all came with their own cultural and religious nuances to feeding, washing, praying and even burial - all of which were overcome in ingenious ways. It became one of the most famous military hospitals in Britain until 1916 when the Indian Army were redeployed to the Middle East theatre. The message: 'Don't be grieved at my death because I shall die arms in hand wearing the warrior's clothes' - Jemadar Indar Singh, Indian Cavalry           The Royal Pavilion in Brighton, pictured, was picked in tribute to the Indian soldiers who were treated there when it was used as a military hospital during the First World War          The pavilion, pictured, became one of the most famous military hospitals in Britain until 1916 when the Indian Army were redeployed to the Middle East theatre  African and Caribbean War Memorial, Brixton, London (Until 29 October)African and Caribbean troops have also been honoured at a memorial in Brixton, which was first unveiled last year.In the First World War many Caribbean men paid their own passage to join the war. Such were their numbers that The British West Indies Regiment was formed. By the end of the war it had 11 Battalions (some 15,000 men) and had won 81 medals for gallantry.  The message: 'Thank You to the Commonwealth, which answered the call in the First World War'           The African and Caribbean War Memorial, unveiled last year in Brixton, has been chosen as one of the linked locations   Neasden Temple, London (Until 29 October) The Neasden Hindu Temple in London has also been chosen for a partner display to pay tribute to the Indian Army for its sacrifices to protect a foreign land. More than 1.5 million Indian Army soldiers served in the Great War, while 70,000 were killed and 11 Victoria Crosses were awarded to their ranks. The BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Temple is the first authentically built Hindu Temple in Great Britain. A Legion spokesman said: '100 years ago such a place would have been beyond imagining but throughout the war soldiers from the Indian Army fought side by side with British and white commonwealth soldiers and, from the chaos of war, cooperation, understanding and mutual respect took root.'The message: 'Do not be anxious my dear friend. Every man whom God created is bound to die someday' - Sepoy Waris Khan, 22nd Regiment, Nowshera           Neasden Temple in London, pictured, was chosen to pay tribute to the Indian Army soldiers who joined the British cause despite living thousands of miles away          More than 1.5 million Indian Army soldiers served in the Great War, while 70,000 were killed and 11 Victoria Crosses were awarded to their ranks. The BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Temple, pictured, is the first authentically built Hindu Temple in Great Britain   Queen Mary's Hospital, Sidcup, Kent (Until 29 October) A memorial has been set up at Queen Mary's Hospital in Sidcup, Kent, to recognise the advances made in plastic surgery during the First World War.Harold Gillies, known as 'the father of plastic surgery', founded a cutting edge facility at the hospital to repair horrific facial wounds suffered by soldiers.By 1925 more than 5,000 patients had been treated and had their lives changed by the pioneering process. The message: 'Before the Great War, men with shattered faces died of wounds or broken hearts. Now they go to a special hospital, where marvels of surgery are performed' - A nurse, on her work with Harold Gillies   The Library of Birmingham (Until 29 October)Birmingham Library was also chosen because of its links to J. R. R. Tolkien, who moved to the city after being born in South Africa, and was inspired by locations around the area for his Hobbit and Lord of the Rings books. When war broke out Tolkien finished his degree at Oxford and joined up in 1915.It was at the Plough and Harrow Hotel in Birmingham, in 1915 that he said farewell to his family and left for the front. Less than a mile from that point the Library of Birmingham now stands and contains Tolkien's works, many of which include elements inspired by his experiences serving as an Officer in the Lancashire Fusiliers. Tolkien served until being medically evacuated from the Somme in 1916 when his battalion was almost entirely wiped out.The message: 'My Sam Gamgee is indeed a reflection of the English soldier, of the privates and batmen I knew in the 1914 war, and recognised as so far superior to myself' - J.R.R Tolkien           The Library of Birmingham, pictured, was chosen for a memorial because of the city's links to J. R. R. Tolkien, who joined the Army in 1915 and served on the Western Front until being medically evacuated from The Somme in 1916  The library, pictured, now contains Tolkien's works, many of which include elements inspired by his experiences serving as an Officer in the Lancashire Fusiliers  Napier University, Edinburgh (Until 29 October) Another literary figure honoured is war poet Wilfred Owen with a display at Napier University in Edinburgh.Owen was traumatised by his experiences on the front lines and was taken to hospital in June 1917 in the city, where he met fellow poet Siegfried Sassoon. What was Craiglockhart Hospital has now become part of the university, thus why it makes up one of the chosen locations.Encouraged by Sassoon, Owen began to write the poems that he was to become most famous for, composing his most iconic works including ‘Anthem for Doomed Youth’. The message: 'Their flowers the tenderness of patient minds, And each slow dusk a drawing-down of blinds.' - Anthem for Doomed Youth, Wilfred Owen: The War Poems           Napier University, pictured, in Edinburgh, was chosen because it was once the site of Craiglockhart Hospital where war poet Wilfred Owen was treated           The hospital, pictured today as a university, was also where Owen met fellow writer Siegfried Sassoon and was inspired to create some of his most famous works  Jack Cornwell Memorial Park, Leyton, London (Until 29 October)The contribution of children to the war effort has also been highlighted with a display at Jack Cornwell Memorial Park in Leyton, London, named after a former boy scout who joined the Royal Navy aged 16 and served in the Battle of Jutland within a year.Cornwell was awarded the Victoria Cross after his gun crew were killed and he was severely wounded by shrapnel in the battle, only to remain at his post and refuse to abandon the position until his ship withdrew from battle. He died in hospital days later but his story was told across the nation and his memory preserved through the park. The message: 'He stayed there, standing and waiting, under heavy fire, with just his own brave heart and God’s help to support him' - Captain Robert Lawson RN of HMS Chester in a letter to Jack Cornwell's mother           Jack Cornwell Memorial Park in Leyton, London, pictured, was picked to honour the contribution of children and teenagers during the war, including Mr Cornwell, who died after valiantly refusing to leave his post despite suffering mortal injuries at sea during the Battle of Jutland          Mr Cornwell's entire gun crew was killed but he stayed in position until his ship withdrew, and was later awarded the Victoria Cross following his death. Pictured is the memorial in the park  We shall knit forget: Display of 15,000 crocheted poppies is placed on town's war memorialBy Rory Tingle for MailOnline An incredible display of 15,000 knitted and crocheted poppies have gone on show at a church to mark the 100th anniversary of the end of World War One.The handmade red flowers at St Peter Mancroft Church in Norwich represent each fallen soldier named on a war memorial in the county.People from across the globe sent in the moving creations after a year-long campaign by Norfolk County Council.          The handmade red flowers at St Peter Mancroft Church in Norwich represent each fallen soldier named on a war memorial in the county  Local brownie and scout groups also made dozens of the flowers, while others came from as far afield as the United StatesSarah Salmon, who works for the local authority and organised the display, said: 'A lot of them have come in with family history stories, which is nice.'Somebody said the best thing was, even though they were following a pattern, each of the poppies is unique, just like the soldiers, and I think that's a really fitting tribute.'Many of the poppies have been made from recycled materials by knitting and crocheting groups based in Norfolk's libraries.Local brownie and scout groups also made dozens of the flowers, while others came from as far afield as the United States.  St Peter Mancroft Church in Norwich (left) and a similar display in Nailsworth, Gloucestershire, (right) where a clock tower was wrapped in 10,000 poppies knitted by locals        Emily Dawes, pictured left, and far right, provoked outrage when she referred to the university's Rotherstein Mural as a 'mural of white men'             Her comments refer to this mural, which depicts an unknown soldier from the First World War being awarded a degree. Local history enthusiasts have asked that it not be damagedBoth she and the students' union have since apologised for her comments after she was accused of abusing the free speech the soldiers fought and died to protect.The Rothenstein Mural was painted in 1916 'as a memorial to members of the British universities serving in the Great War'.'It depicts an academic procession and the conferring of a degree on an unknown soldier,' according to the university.Lucy Carter, the granddaughter of mural artist Sir William Rothenstein, said of Ms Dawes's comments: 'I think it's very sad, people trying to change history.              The University of Southampton Students' Union President Emily Dawes has provoked anger with this tweet threatening to paint over a First World War memorial            She also posted this tweet, suggesting she understood the significance of the mural'It's sad that people should be overtaken by these concerns. Painting over it would be unnecessary.'Southampton MP Royston Smith, who served in the RAF for ten years, said the SU president's tweet was 'disappointing' considering the soldiers were defending the free speech which she was exercising.He said: 'With freedom comes responsibility, and considering the President of the SU holds a position of authority she has clearly overstepped the mark.'I hope she will reflect on what she has said and realise it has been conducted in poor taste. Those who know the history of our island are fully aware and appreciate the involvement of black and Asian soldiers against tyranny.' The university's Conservative Association called for Ms Dawes to face disciplinary action and said the mural should be protected from potential vandalism. After she was criticised today, Ms Dawes released a statement saying: 'Firstly, and most importantly, I would like to apologise for the offense and upset I have caused with what I have said.             Her comments have provoked anger from many in the city, who pointed out the bravery of those who fought and died in the First World War'I never meant to the disrespect to anyone past, present and future. 'I had no intention of the tweet being taken literally, and upon reflection have realised how inappropriate it was.'My intention was to promote strong, female leadership and not the eradication and disrespect of history. I do not believe that to make progress in the future, we should look to raise the past.'The controversial Twitter post was not the only tweet she aimed at the memorial. She had earlier tweeted a picture of the wall, with the expletive-ridden message: 'ONE OF THE WOMEN JUST SAID 'it's nearly armistice day so are we covering up this tapestry??' AND HOLY S***. F*** YES. GRL PWR #sotonsenatelive'. Ms Dawes, whose family live in Virginia in the US, previously attended the £5,000-a-term Northwood College for Girls in north London, according to her LinkedIn page.     Ms Dawes is one of eight sabbatical officers who represents students at the university            The controversial Twitter post was not the only tweet she aimed at the memorial            The physics student, who was previously president of the university's Feminist Society, says her favourite thing about Southampton is the 'pretty dope' vegan food            The university says it is proud of the mural, which shows an 'unknown soldier' getting a degree            Students in Oxford call for a statue of Cecil Rhodes to be removed in 2016The union insisted the move was designed to 'broaden the focus to include those who suffered and died wherever they were in the world'. Last year,  professor Nigel Biggar came under fire after he said society should take a more balanced view of the Empire rather than simply remembering it with shame.He acknowledged 'atrocities' had occurred under colonial rule, but said it had also provided law and order in other countries that many citizens had valued.But student campaigners at Oxford called his article 'racist' and claimed it 'whitewashed' the British Empire.                                                      The Royal British Legion | UK charity for British Armed Forces, reservists, veterans and their families

title: Tony Abbott Brussels NEVER make real concessions Brexit
story: Brussels will never make real concessions to 'desperate' Britain, former Australian prime minister Tony Abbott (file image) has warned          Westminster has been rife with rumours Mrs May (pictured in Downing Street yesterday) is about to be ousted by frustrated Brexit supporters but she has again escaped a series of tests unscathedWriting in the Spectator, he said trading on World Trade Organisation worked 'pretty well for Australia' and would also work for Britain. He said: 'A world trade Brexit lets Britain set its own rules. It can say, right now, that it will not impose any tariff or quota on European produce and would recognise all EU product standards.'That means no border controls for goods coming from Europe to Britain. You don’t need to negotiate this: just do it.'It wasn't a lion's den, it was more like a petting zoo':...Tory MP Andrew Bridgen accuses No 10 of making up threats to...Share this article'If Europe knows what’s in its own best interests, it would fully reciprocate in order to maintain entirely free trade and full mutual recognition of standards right across Europe.' Mr Abbott said there should also be a unilateral declaration of protection for EU citizen's rights and reformed free movement for workers - but not benefit claimants.He said: 'No ‘orce bill’ whatsoever should be paid to Brussels. The UK government would assume the EU’s property and liabilities in Britain, and the EU would assume Britain’s share of these in Europe.          He said the obvious reluctance of Britain to walk away without a deal was not negotiation but 'surrender' to an opponent in Michel Barnier (pictured on Tuesday in Strasbourg) with a 'palpable desire to punish Britain''If Britain was getting its fair share, these would balance out and if Britain wasn’t getting its fair share, it’s the EU that should be paying Britain.'The former PM continued: 'Of course, the EU might not like this British leap for independence. It might hit out with tariffs and impose burdens on Britain as it does on the US — but WTO rules put a cap on any retaliatory action.'The worst it can get? We’re talking levies of an average 4 or 5 per cent. Which would be more than offset by a post-Brexit devaluation of the pound.'   Tony Abbott: How to save Brexit | The Spectator

title: Halloween mad grandmother 51 spends hundreds kitting home spooky shrine
story: Mary Flynn (right), 51, has raised around £10,000 for charities as a result of her Halloween display - which features ghosts and ghouls, gravestones, witches and zombies. This years she will be raising money for Zoe's Place Baby Hospice. She is pictured here with her daughter Lisa Flynn, 30          Ms Flynn got married on to husband Dave, 54, on Halloween 32 years ago. She now receives ghostly gifts from family members to mark her wedding anniversary. A lot of these end up featuring in her annual Halloween display  Ms Flynn's grandson seven-year-old Brodie Roberts is seen enjoying the spirit of Halloween in the front garden of Ms Flynn's home (pictured). He is pictured here next to a gargoyle, just one of the many spooky figures on display at the property          Hundreds have flocked to the house in Liverpool over the years, where Ms Flynn awaits with sweets for any brave trick or treaters. The display is particularly impressive at night time when a projector shows zombies appearing to prowl around the bedroom upstairsShe said: 'I've been doing this for about six years now and it's become a real attraction.'It started with a ghost I put up in the window for my three daughters then we got a couple of gravestones and it's grown from there.'Now I'd say I've got well over a hundred items.'On Halloween it's bedlam. We probably get thousands of people turning up and the road gets blocked up.'Come 6pm it's really busy in the run up to Halloween. We get on average 200 people throughout the day.'Chilling killer clown warning ahead of Halloween approaches...'Haunted' house for sale (spirits included): Abandoned...Can you see a ghost? Visitor to Henry VIII castle films 'a...Share this articleA giant spider can be seen crawling over her front window, a black gazebo houses a group of witches while ghoulish heads sit on top of the garage in a display which takes her three days to put together.The gran-of-five said so many fans turn up to snap the spooky sight they frequently block the road in the run up to October 31.   Ms Flynn now receives ghostly gifts from family members to mark her wedding anniversary to husband Dave, 54, who she has been married to for 32 years this October 31.She said: 'People say it's fantastic. The kids don't want to go home. They love it.'Some of the kids are scared but still want to come back. It's so lovely to see a smile on their faces.'There's pensioners who come down to see it from the nursing home.'Before we started decorating this year there was a child on their way to school and I could hear him whispering 'there's the Halloween lady'. I thought 'I've never been called that before'.          Ms Flynn's home (left) is a stark contrast to her next-door neighbour's (right), who has not got any decorations up at all. The quiet suburban estate in which they both live comes to life on Halloween as hundreds flock to the home, often blocking the road as they do so  Grizzly figurines adorn the windows and doors of the home (left and right). Ms Flynn claims that even though a few of the children are scared by the display, they still end up wanting to come back          The display is particularly impressive at night time (pictured) when a projector shows zombies appearing to prowl around the bedroom upstairs. Ms Flynn claims the scene was so realistic that three old ladies even asked who she'd got to dress up for itOver the years, Ms Flynn believes her display has attracted hundreds. She's always on the hunt for new figurines but luckily her family members are often donating items.She said: 'Family members often buy stuff and we all throw our pennies in a pot through the year so we can buy things come Halloween.' Ms Flynn is always stocked with sweets for trick or treaters which she hands out to any brave enough to enter the display.It is particularly impressive at night time when a projector shows zombies appearing to prowl around the bedroom upstairs.Ms Flynn claims the scene was so realistic that three old ladies even asked who she'd got to dress up for it.She now stands in her front garden with a bucket every evening in the run up to Halloween - and has raised thousands of pounds for charity over the years.Ms Flynn, who is raising money for Zoe's Place Baby Hospice, said: 'We've had strangers donating things. We came home last year and there was a big box of mannequin heads on the doorstep. We wrapped material around them and put masks on them so they could go on the garage.'We had a donation from the local shop thanks to one of their staff members who has been coming to see it with his son for the last five years. He came with a gravestone and three big bags of sweets.          Many of the figurines in the garden light up at night time giving the display an especially spooky feel. Among the attractions is a ghost that goes up and down, a giant spider above a window and four witches sitting around a table and lots of graves  Ms Flynn's grandson seven-year-old Brodie Roberts and her niece 18-month-old Thea-Rose Kola (both right) enjoy the spooky Halloween house, while surrounded by grizzly figurines (left). Ms Flynn has spent thousands getting her display to the level it is at now          Gargoyles and gravestones fill the garden of Ms Flynn's home, which she hopes will help her raise hundreds of pounds for Zoe's Place Baby Hospice - her chosen charity for this yearAmong the attractions is a ghost that goes up and down, a giant spider above a window and four witches sitting around a table and lots of graves.  Ms Flynn said: 'The children say 'it's sick' which my daughter tells me means it's good.'People started knocking on the door asking where they could leave the money so we thought we'd start doing it for charity. We started standing outside with a bucket.'The first year we raised cash for Macmillan and for the last few years for Alder Hey Children's Hospital. We've raised about £10,000 for them over the last couple of years.'

title: Russia bids BLOCK Britain inheriting EUs import quotas Brexit
story: The UK will rely on WTO rules and procedures after leaving the EU. Pictured is the body's director general Roberto AzevêdoThe EU and Britain agreed in July to maintain current rates and split their quotas based on existing trade flows.But the UK's chances of using a 'rectification' procedure to speed up the process have been dealt a blow by the objections,Russia - which is embroiled in a bitter dispute with the UK over the Skripal poisoning - is arguing that the full scheduling arrangements must be followed as the EU's list has not been ratified by all states since the accession of Croatia in 2013.A WTO official who was present at a meeting earlier this month told the MLex news website: 'The Russian Federation reiterated that the resolution of the issue of certification of the EU schedule seems to be pivotal to proceed with the new UK schedule.'Britain must be ready for a French 'go slow' designed to...Brussels will NEVER make any real concessions on Brexit...Share this articleAltogether about 20 members of the WTO are said to have raised concerns about the proposals. The US and New Zealand are believed to have issues, although they are not thought to be determined to torpedo the process.The WTO has 164 member states and was set up in 1995 to regulate trade and settle disputes.The Department for International Trade played down the problem, saying it was 'not uncommon' for members to object.A spokeswoman said there were 'well-established processes' for resolving such issues.The UK would rely on the WTO rules for trade with the EU if there is no deal struck post-Brexit. Doubts have been raised about the way the organisation functions after US president Donald Trump blocked the appointments of judges - reportedly undermining its ability to rule on disputes.          The PM (pictured at No10 yesterday) managed to quell restive Conservative MPs by delivering an emotional plea for support at what had been billed as a 'show trial' meeting last night

title: Prank caller Jeremy Vine stuns viewers calling Anne Diamond big fat c live air
story: Anne Diamond (pictured) did not look impressed and immediately apologised to viewers for the foul languageThe Blackpool-based caller shouts out Anne Diamond is a 'big fat c*** live on air- appalling viewers of the Channel 5 show.Ever the professional, the 64-year-old TV presenter sighed, said 'Thank you very much', and then immediately apologised to viewers for the profanity laced outburst.Social media users were in shock with the sudden change in tone of the apparently cordial conservation about social media use.           Anne Diamond was standing in for usual presenter Jeremy Vine (pictured). The 64-year-old was discussing social media sharing when the rude outburst occurred      'He used self-induced vomiting to let go of nerves': Wife of...Lest we forget: Royal British Legion unveils 20ft-high poppy...Share this articleOne user said: 'Poor Anne Diamond. The man who called in, what a disgrace. Shame on you.'And another said: 'Oh my god someone who called in just called Anne Diamond a 'big fat c***' live on morning telly #JeremyVine But other social media users had a different theory and came to the defense of the caller, who they thought may have had Tourette's Syndrome.One angry user said: '#jeremyvine Dreadful treatment of a caller who obviously had Tourette's! Where's the compassion!'          Tourette's is a neurological condition characterised by a combination of involuntary noises and movements, called tics.It usually starts during childhood and continues into adulthood, the tics can be either vocal or physical.The syndrome is named after French doctor Georges Gilles de la Tourette, who first described the syndrome and its symptoms in the 19th century.
