story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsAnalysts said the currency had been 'spooked' ahead of the Prime Minister's meeting with Tory rebels on WednesdayClick to followThe IndependentPound sterling fell to a six-week low against the dollar on Wednesday, as Theresa May fought to win over Tory party colleagues who disapprove of her approach to the Brexit negotiations. The pound dropped 0.5 per cent to $1.29, the lowest level since early September.Connor Campbell at Spreadex said sterling’s downward trajectory was “unsurprising”. “It appears that the currency has been spooked by Theresa May’s impending meeting with the 1922 Committee of Tory backbenchers, with whom the PM hardly has the best relationship with at the moment (even before the rather violent comments reported in the papers over the weekend). A no-deal Brexit would seriously threaten our national securityBritain Before Brexit: a portrait of the country and its peopleVoters 'deserve a final say on Brexit', leader of EU socialists says“The outcome of that address may impact how the Brexit negotiations move forward – or don’t, as the troublesome case may be.”Over the weekend, media reports emerged with Tory rebels using aggressive and violent language to attack the prime minister, including one who warned that Ms May should “bring her own noose” if she decided to come to the 1922 meeting. MPs were quoted as saying she was now entering “the killing zone” and that “assassination is in the air”, while another unnamed Tory was quoted as saying: “The moment is coming when the knife gets heated, stuck in her front and twisted. She’ll be dead soon.” Ms May confirmed on Tuesday that she would meet with the backbench 1922 Committee.David Cheetham, chief market analyst at broker XTB, said: “May’s position is similar to that of the pound in that it seems to be carrying on despite the sizable challenges faced.If May was toppled the pound would see a wave of selling in the short-term since her replacement could increase the chances of a no-deal Brexit, Cheetham added.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: sainburys oasis deal fashion tu supermarket retail clothing concessions
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSupermarket has announced a string of deals aimed at expanding into new markets and growing customer baseClick to followThe IndependentSainsbury’s has announced a new partnership with high street fashion brand Oasis, with plans to open five concessions in store by next spring. The companies said the pair-up is expected to be a success because Sainsbury’s and Oasis cater to very similar demographics. Two Oasis concessions will open at Sainsbury’s supermarkets before Christmas at Sydenham in south London and at Selly Oak, near Birmingham. Sainsbury's sales growth slows as it slashes pricesSainsbury’s launches new vegan range due to increasing demandMPs accuse Sainsbury’s of giving staff ultimatum over new pay dealsSainsbury’s said these two locations had been “carefully selected” because they are stores where the Tu clothing range performs “particularly strongly”. Sainsbury’s director of commercial, James Brown, said: “We are delighted to be welcoming Oasis to Sainsbury’s stores. Its on-trend fashion ranges will complement our high quality Tu clothing offer and support our strategy to make our stores leading fashion destinations.”Hash Ladha, chief executive designate of Oasis, said: “Trialling Oasis in Sainsbury’s is an exciting development for us. This is about presenting the Oasis product proposition and brand experience to Sainsbury’s customers. The customer demographic of both brands is very similar and therefore it is a natural strategic partnership.”This is the latest in a string of deals Sainsbury’s has executed in a bid to ersify its offering and grow its customer base. The retailer has previously agreed partnerships with Clarks and Specsavers. Meanwhile, the group is in the process of buying Asda, which will make it the UK’s biggest retailer, ahead of Tesco, if the deal completes. The companies are waiting for regulatory approval from the competition watchdog, which may require the closure of hundreds of stores before the takeover can go ahead. The CMA has said it will assess whether the merger “could lead to a worse outcome for shoppers through higher prices, a poorer shopping experience, or reductions in the range or quality of products offered”.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? title: home office immigration status dna evidence sajid javid government conservative
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsSajid Javid&nbspapologises to Gurkha soldiers and Afghan nationals who were among those&nbspillegally required to provide DNA evidence to prove&nbspfamily ties in ‘deeply troubling’&nbspHome Office admissionClick to followThe IndependentThe Home Office has admitted that people have been wrongly denied&nbspUK status after refusing to provide DNA evidence in a breach of its own policy.Sajid Javid, the home secretary,&nbspsaid&nbspthe government had illegally demanded DNA evidence in family visa cases, with at least seven people denied the right to stay in Britain because they refused to provide DNA samples to prove family ties.He apologised to those affected, who included relatives of Gurkha soldiers,&nbspand announced&nbspthat a new taskforce had been set up for anyone who believed&nbspthey had been wrongly asked to provide DNA.Home Office immigration delays double as thousands ‘left in limbo’Politicians and campaigners described the revelation as “deeply troubling” and another sign that, following the&nbspWindrush&nbspscandal, there was an&nbspurgent&nbspneed for&nbsp”root and branch reform” in&nbspthe Home Office.Speaking to the House of Commons on Thursday, Mr Javid said: “At the end of June we became aware of some immigration cases where the provision of DNA&nbspevidence had been made a requirement – and it was not simply a request.“Such demands are unacceptable. Today, I want to take the opportunity to apologise to those affected by this practice.”The home secretary said the majority of cases identified had been part of a 2016 operation aimed at addressing fraud.He said&nbspseven cases in this operation were refused on suitability grounds solely for the failure to provide DNA evidence, and a further six were refused partly for that reason.Fifty-one further cases have&nbspbeen identified as part of a 2013 scheme&nbspto allow relatives of Gurkha soldiers to settle in the UK, which wrongly stated that DNA evidence was required, Mr Javid said.A third scheme assessed immigration applications from Afghan nationals working for the UK&nbspgovernment on the basis of mandatory DNA testing. Mr Javid&nbspsaid no one from&nbspthis cohort&nbsphad been refused on these grounds.He said his&nbspdepartment would seek to reimburse any inidual who has suffered financial loss as a result of the errors and was continuing&nbspto closely examine whether any other groups had been affected.Home Office forcing immigrants to take DNA tests against own policyHe also said he was taking action to correct the situation&nbspand had given “clear instructions” that officials should not seek DNA samples. The provision of DNA evidence must be entirely voluntary, he added.Expanding on his apology, Mr Javid&nbspsaid: “It is not fair, and this should not have happened. No one should have faced a demand to provide DNA evidence and no one should have been penalised for not providing it.”It comes after it emerged in July that a&nbspletter had been sent by the Home Office to an applicant’s solicitor stating that it was “imperative” they submit DNA evidence to confirm the paternity of their client’s child, despite the fact that the child already had a British passport.The applicant's solicitor, Enny Choudhury, of&nbspthe Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants (JCWI), said:&nbsp“My client and her child were rendered destitute for 2.5 years as a direct result of the Home Office’s illegal practices.It is clear that countless others will have been subject to the same treatment and it is astonishing that ministers still do not have a grasp on the failings of the Home Office.We agree with the home secretary that there must be a review, but it must be fully independent of him and his Home Office. No one could have faith in its competence to properly investigate its own failings.” &nbspYvette Cooper, chair of the Home Affairs Committee, said: “Coming after&nbspWindrush, this shows something is going very wrong in the Home Office again.&nbsp“A new wider review must be independent and should examine oversight failure and impact of policies on culture of Home Office operations.”Steve Valdez-Symonds, of Amnesty UK, said the&nbspHome Office had “once again been exposed as being a law unto itself”.He added: “The home secretary needs to face up to the fact that problems in his department are systemic, chronic and deep-rooted.&nbsp“Over several decades, successive governments have consistently encouraged policies and practice which disrespect the law and harm the people directly affected.“This dysfunctional department cannot continue to be rewarded by being given more powers while vital safeguards, such as appeal rights and legal aid, are stripped away.&nbsp“Root and branch reform is urgently needed and protections restored to keep the Home Office in check.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: brexit final say demonstration london peoples vote numbers theresa may
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options‘We were the few, and now we are the many,’&nbspactivists told as huge crowds urge Theresa May to change courseClick to followIndy PoliticsThe crowds stretched so far back that plenty of people never even made it to the rally.Masses overflowed through the streets of London for more than a mile, from Hyde Park Corner to Parliament Square, as an estimated 670,000 protesters took their demand for a fresh Brexit referendum right to Theresa May’s doorstep.They came from every corner of the UK, in what is believed to be the largest demonstration since the Iraq War march in 2003, when more than a million people turned out in the capital to oppose the conflict.Second referendum would not be an affront to democracy, far from itAmid the swathes of EU flags and banners, there was also a growing sense that campaigners, MPs and activists were realising, perhaps for the first time, that this was a battle that could be won.“We were the few, and now we are the many,” Tory MP Anna Soubry told the crowds crammed into Parliament Square.“We are winning the argument and we are winning the argument most importantly against those who voted Leave.”She said: “We will not walk away. We will take responsibility and sort out this mess with a people’s vote.”Speaking to The Independent beforehand, she said many Tory MPs were privately supportive of a second referendum amid bitter isions in the party.Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran said the sheer scale of the event showed that “confidence is growing” in the fight for a fresh vote.To huge cheers, London mayor Sadiq Khan said the march marked a&nbsp“historic moment in our democracy”.Over 700,000 protesters’ call for second Brexit referendumTheresa May told she’s ‘heading for dead end’ in Brexit talksThe collective spreading cheer to Brexit-weary BritsEx-cabinet secretaries condemn Tory Brexiteers for undermining MayFinal Say: Meet some of the people marching a fresh Brexit vote He told protestors: “We’ve heard some complain that a public vote would be undemocratic and unpatriotic. But the opposite is true.“There’s nothing more democratic – nothing more British – than trusting the people to have the final say on our future.”MPs from across the political spectrum addressed the rally, including Green MP Caroline Lucas, Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable, Labour’s Chuka Umunna and Tory MP Dr Sarah Wollaston, who drew huge cheers when she compared&nbspBrexit to a botched operation.Christian Broughton, editor of The Independent,&nbsptold the crowds: “Theresa May says that the Final Say referendum will be a politicians’ vote, not a people’s vote, but we can all remember what some politicians told us in 2016.“We, the people, can all now see what’s really coming. And from where I’m standing it looks like a people’s vote to me.”He revealed that The Independent’s petition for a Final Say had achieved more than 940,000 signatures, adding: “We have to keep on showing up and signing up.”People did show up in their thousands for the march, which was extremely cheerful, except for a handful of Ukip protestors who screamed&nbsp“Losers”&nbspat passers-by from outside Downing Street.An army of students, college pupils and young activists led the march in a sign of the impact of the Brexit vote on the younger generation, some 1.4 million of whom have become eligible to vote since the referendum.Femi Oluwole, from the youth group Our Future Our Choice, told The Independent: “What we are trying to do is bring people together, as nobody has any confidence in what the government is doing.”He said young people were going to be hit hardest by Brexit, both economically and in the opportunities to live and work abroad.Among the crowds was Piero Passet, a 71-year-old restaurant owner from Turin, said he was marching because he was concerned for the future of the younger generation.Created with Sketch.Brexit march for a final say – in pictures Show all 26Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Final Say campaigners take part in the peoples vote march for the future in London 20102018Final Say campaigners take part in the peoples vote march for the future in London 20102018Final Say campaigners take part in the peoples vote march for the future in LondonDemonstrators pass Trafalgar Square as they take part in a march calling for a People's Vote on the final Brexit deal, in central London on October 20, 2018. - I don’t think that’s fair.Broughton speaks at the People’s Vote march in London“I think there are lots of people who are absolutely engaged but were excluded from the vote.”&nbspAlso among the crowds was Lord Of The Rings actor Andy Serkis, who described it as “one of the most, if not the most important march of a generation”.Other famous faces included Sir Bob Geldof, TV presenter Richard Bacon, Dragons’ Den star Deborah Meaden, comedian Jenny Eclair and Holby City actors Catherine Russell and Hugh Quarshie.Ahead of the march, a Downing Street spokeswoman told The Independent that people had a right to speak out, but that the prime minister had made clear her position in regards to a new referendum.While the protestors gathered, Ms May visited an exhibition in her constituency, entitled Maidenhead And Me, featuring work by local artists.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - PoliticsMPs are far more likely to reject any Brexit deal if they are denied the chance to amend it in a proper “meaningful vote”, Theresa May has been warned.A controversial move to only allow the Commons to accept or reject an agreement with the EU – preventing any amendments – will backfire by increasing opposition, Tory rebel Dominic Grieve predicted.“If the government tries to pursue the route they are opting for, it is far more likely that the deal is likely to be rejected,” the former attorney general told an inquiry by MPs.“You are confronted with an all-or-nothing choice – and you will not be able to go on and talk about anything else until you have rejected the deal.”Senior Tories round on May over U-turn on meaningful Brexit voteMr Grieve – whose revolt, last December, won the “meaningful vote” – called for the debate to last 4 or 5 days, to let every MP “have their say”.And he warned they would be “much more hostile” if they were denied the chance to make amendments until after “the guillotine has fallen” and the deal approved.“To go back on this, or to try to avoid it, would be wrong – and it would be a big mistake,” he said.The comments come after Dominic Raab, the Brexit secretary, was accused of breaking an earlier pledge, in a letter sent to the Commons procedure committee last week.MPs had been told they would be able to bring forward an amendment requiring a Final Say referendum on the outcome of the talks, or perhaps to keep the UK in the EU single market or customs union.Created with Sketch.Brexit march for a final say – in pictures Show all story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsUdo Bullmann&nbspcites 'lies' spread during first referendum and 700,000&nbsptaking to the streetsClick to followIndy PoliticsThe British public should be given a Final Say referendum on any Brexit deal Theresa May strikes with the EU, the leader of the socialist group in the European Parliament has said.Udo Bullmann said “the lies of the Brexiteers” and the strength of support shown at last weekend’s&nbspmarch in London meant a vote now had to be on the cards.The intervention by the leader of the centre-left group&nbspof which Labour is a member, is a major boost for The Independent’s Final Say campaign.It's too late to prepare UK borders for no-deal Brexit, watchdog warns“Last Saturday we saw some 700,000 people marching in London to have a Final Say on a possible Brexit deal,” Mr Bullmann told a debate in the European Parliament on Wednesday morning.“We think the British people deserve, once they have seen the measures and the consequences of this orce, once they have seen the lies of the Brexiteers, the British people deserve to have a Final Say on their future. name&nbspSir Philip Green as the businessman who obtained a privacy injunction&nbspover&nbspbullying and sexual harassment allegations.Labour peer, Lord Hain, said it was his duty to out the&nbsphigh official spokesman said: The Budget is always a significant event for business and the country at large so it is an opportunity to update some of the core messages from the Budget.But equally we are story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsExclusive: The study marks the death knell for&nbsptraditional class-based views of how voters actClick to followIndy PoliticsExperts have devised a revolutionary new system for classifying voters that could hand political parties the key to unlocking victory at the next general election, The Independent can reveal.The project headed by BMG Research drives a horse and carriage through traditional class-based views of how voters act and instead ides them into 10 electoral “clans”.After interviewing almost 30,000 people over a year, researchers identified the distinct values of each clan and the issues on which they overlap – with parties able to politically position themselves on these sweet spots, standing to gain the backing of multiple groups.Backing Remain would risk abandoning Labour’s working-class votersToday BMG are launching a new online tool exclusively with The Independent, which allows anyone to discover which clan they belong to and to access data pointing to how groups may vote come 2022.The study, a collaboration with academics in Bristol and Manchester, also offers a valuable insight into the politics of Brexit, which have cleaved through the traditional voting coalitions relied on by the major parties.Dr Michael Turner, BMG’s research director and the report’s lead author, said: “All political parties are coalitions of voters with different priorities, and these coalitions are changing.“The old way of looking at the world, through demographic factors such as social class, age, education, and where we live – all have much smaller influences on the way we vote compared to values and identity politics.“The research team have also created an incredibly powerful and engaging tool, so the public can understand for themselves, what these clans are and how they differ, revealing the siloed and fractured nature of our politics at this time.”The study interviewed 27,000 people to identify the “like-minded values groups”, and then devised 27 “golden questions” which if answered by any voter allows them to be categorised into one of the clans.Identified groups include those such as the “Bastions of Tradition and&nbspthe Inidual” clan, the “Strength, Agreeable and Respect” clan, the “Modern Working Life” group and the “Notting Hill Society”.The biggest single clan is the “Proud and Patriotic State”, making up some 15 per cent of the voting public and tending to favour redistribution of wealth, nationalisation of key industries and with a strong dislike of multiculturalism and freedom of movement.Next biggest is the “Common Sense Solidarity” clan, which are&nbspalso strong supporters of renationalisation and trade unions and believe firmly in the redistribution of wealth via taxation.But while these two groups share a desire for left-wing economic policy, they are fundamentally ided over multiculturalism, with “Common Sense Solidarity” members far more at ease with immigration – the two groups were on opposite sides of the Brexit debate.Created with Sketch.The ten voter clans of the British electorate Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created Understanding the ‘clans’ offers valuable insights into who might want what from Brexit and how this might affect future elections, or indeed referendum outcomes.”Between the 2015 and 2017 election both Labour and the Tories increased their share in many of the groups, squeezing out smaller parties.Created with Sketch.How big are the UK's voter clans and how do they vote? growth in turnout from liberal, left-of-centre groups, the “Global Green Community”, up by almost 8 per cent, and “Common Sense Solidarity”, up by more than 4 per cent – with both groups overwhelmingly falling in behind Mr Corbyn’s Labour.Overall the Conservatives were ahead across a greater range of groups – in seven of the 10 clans three years ago, down to six last year.The only group that changed allegiance was the “Orange Book” clan – connected to Nick Clegg’s Liberal Democrats – which tipped from overall support for the Tories in 2015, to marginal backing for Labour in story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsAcademic suggests prime minister deliberately misquoted him in order to 'gain political effect' in attack on LabourClick to followIndy PoliticsA leading economist has accused Theresa May of lying&nbspduring Prime Minister's Questions, claiming she&nbspdeliberately misquoted him.Simon Wren-Lewis, a professor at Oxford University, strongly denied&nbspthe prime minister's suggestion that he had said the&nbspfigures in Labour's last manifesto did not add up.The claim appeared to be&nbspa deliberate&nbsplie told to gain political effect, he said.Ms May made the comment during a clash with Jeremy Corbyn at&nbspPMQs on Wednesday.Sterling falls to six-week low as Theresa May faces Brexit backlashShe did not directly name Mr Wren-Lewis&nbspbut referred to a chapter he wrote&nbspfor&nbspa book, titled Economics for the Many, that was edited by John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor.&nbspMr Wren-Lewis is&nbspan informal adviser to Mr McDonnell.Mr Wren-Lewis hit back within minutes, denying that he had&nbspsaid Labour's figures were wrong. Instead, he said, he had argued that claims by the Institute for Fiscal Studies&nbspthat&nbspthe party's costings contained factual mistakes were irrelevant.He wrote on Twitter: Apparently the prime minister quoted me saying about Labour's 2017 manifesto 'the numbers did not add up'. In fact I said 'let us suppose the IFS was correct' and examined consequences. I have never taken a view on whether they diddidn't add up. If that is what she said, she lied.In a blog post titled The day Theresa May lied in parliament about something I wrote, he continued: The point I wanted to stress was that it didn’t matter if the IFS were right that the numbers didn’t add up, because the fiscal stance was good for the economy, and could well satisfy Labour's very good Fiscal Credibility Rule.Of the prime minister's comments, he said: Was this an unfortunate case of misreading? It seems extremely implausible. I’m certain that when the PM or more probably some adviser misquotes someone in a draft PMQ response, someone - possibly even the person themselves - checks that the quote is correct. You have to have serious comprehension difficulties to misunderstand the meaning of 'let us suppose'.He suggested Ms May's claim was a deliberate&nbsplie told to gain political effect but said he would be&nbspwilling to accept it was an honest mistake if the prime minister&nbspor someone from her team could explain how it happened.&nbspHe said: In the scheme of things the issue is very minor, but the prime minister&nbsplying whatever the context should be important. But the sad thing is that no one is surprised by this kind of thing any more.We in the UK look at Trump’s lying with horror and think this is something uniquely American. But this government has been pulled up countless time&nbspfor misleading the public by misusing statistics and of course the lies of the Brexiters are shameless.Mr Wren-Lewis said he had&nbspasked the Conservative Party for an apology but was not holding my breath.The matter was raised in the Commons by Peter Dowd, the shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, who suggested Ms May should apologise.Khan warns Labour MPs not to 'blackmailed' over PM's Brexit dealUK to 'revoke Saudi suspects' visas today' over Khashoggi's murderMay confirms she will attend showdown meeting with Tory rebelsMay sidesteps rebels with plans to enshrine Brexit proposal in lawMaking a point of order, he said: During Prime Minister’s Questions, the prime minister asserted that the respected Oxford economist and professor, Simon Wren-Lewis, said, in reference to Labour’s manifesto, 'the numbers did not add up'.However, Professor Wren-Lewis disputes the accuracy of those remarks.Quoting&nbspthe academic's tweet, he added: Would it be appropriate for the prime minister to come back to this House to correct the record and apologise to the renowned professor in question?The deputy speaker, Eleanor Laing,&nbspsaid she was sure Ms May's comments were made in good faith and that&nbspit was not her job to assess the accuracy of claims made in the Commons.No 10 has been contacted for title: Brexit news UK EU Dominic Raab European Union Commons Michel Barnier
story: Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab attacked the European Union over its approach to negotiations warning no deal could become a reality.At the Brussels summit last week EU leaders decided to push back the November summit until &ldquodecisive progress is made in negotiations.Speaking in the House of Commons on Thursday morning the Brexit Secretary was asked about preparations made for UK ports.Labour MP Gerald Jones asked: &ldquoThe recent national audit office estimate that if customs declarations are required for trade between the UK and the EU the total number of declarations could increase by around 360 percent, from 55 million currently on non-EU trade to 225million.                Brexit deal could be saved by Labour rebels, says LEO McKINSTRY&ldquoWhat estimate has the Minister made on additional staff that would be required and not least the likely tailbacks that could ensue at UK ports.&rsquoThe Conservative frontbencher responded with a furious dig at the European Union's Brexit approach.Mr&nbspRaab said: &ldquoThere&nbspcertainly&nbspis a risk of no deal especially if the EU engage in a deliberately intransigent approach.&ldquoHe asked about&nbspstaff,&nbspwe&rsquore recruiting 300 extra staff with a further 600 planned.Brexit news: Dominic Raab sent a fiery warning to the EU in the Commons (Image: PARLIAMENTTV)&ldquoWe have given a range of advice through our 106 technical notices, half of which gave advice on customs procedures from businesses.&ldquoThere have been 300,000 letters sent to current customs users and letters to 145,000 VAT registered businesses.Speaking on the BBC&rsquos The Andrew Marr Show on Sunday, the Brexit Secretary warned the European Union that they would not be able to &ldquocherry pick from the Prime Minister&rsquos controversial Chequers blueprint.Asked about whether he expected a summit in November,&nbspMr&nbspRaab replied: &ldquoI am confident we can get a&nbspdeal and&nbspequally I think we need to have done it towards the end of November. There is every reason we can do this deal, there&nbspis&nbsppragmatism and goodwill on both sides.&ldquoBut, what we are not going to do, and I think this is an important point to make Andrew, we have made concessions, we have made compromises, there does come a point where you can be compromised yourselves by the compromises you make.Despite no progress at last weeks Brussels summit, the Prime Minister left optimistic a deal could still be reached.Speaking to reporters after the summit,&nbspTheresa&nbspMay said: &ldquoWhat I have had from leaders around the table over the last hours... since I arrived here in Brussels yesterday, is a very real sense that people want that deal to be done.&ldquoAnd I think if you look at some of the comments that have been made, Chancellor Merkel said where there is a will there's normally a way.

title: make this budget philips last
story: Next Monday, on the eve of Halloween, Phil Hammond will raise the curtain on his latest tax-hiking non-Tory Budget.If there’s any justice, it will be his last.If Theresa May’s Downing Street days are numbered, so should those be of her Death Watch Chancellor.Together, they are the unrivalled stars of Tory MP Johnny Mercer’s glorious Whitehall farce, “The Sh*t Show”.Excitable critics say Mrs May is entering a “killing zone”.Rivals jockey for position while party chiefs try to streamline the timetable for picking her successor.This Prime Minister’s Number Ten tenancy is almost up. So is Hammond’s next door.Whoever takes over — Boris, David Davis or Jeremy Hunt — needs an emergency clear-out.The big guns of the Treasury need to be pointed at the “enemy” not its own side.After two long, wasted years, Britain is engaged in an unexpectedly desperate fight, not just to salvage Brexit but to save British democracy.Weekend crowds demanding a second referendum seem oblivious to the threat such a crazy re-run would pose to this nation’s centuries-old stability, ironically the envy of Europe.We cannot reverse the  referendum without turning Brexit into a perpetual running sore. And Britain can never rejoin the EU except on its knees.The only way to put this corrosive issue to bed is for Brexit to succeed — as it will, despite treacherous Tony Blair and Facebook hypocrite Nick Clegg.To succeed as we must we need a new chancellor as well as a new prime minister.Diehard Remainer Phil Hammond should be first out the door.It was Spreadsheet Phil who vetoed vital preparations for No Deal — now a better-than - prospect with time rapidly running out.And it was Hammond who surrendered the one negotiating weapon Brussels fears most — a thriving, low-tax Britain competing with the EU on its doorstep.Our economic fate is entirely in our hands. We can make taxes and tarfs as competitive as we like.Better investment incentives and lower corporation tax rates would trigger a flood of foreign investment in UK plc — and ensure car makers like Nissan and Toyota never leave our shores.Yet the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has ruled them out.“Phil is like those Harry Potter Dementor creatures,” says a top Tory. “He sucks the le out of any room he happens to be in.”Hammond is easily replaced. Michael Gove, an ex-future PM but a formidable Cabinet minister, has the drive and imagination to take on the Treasury “Blob”.There is no shortage of Brexit talent on the Tory benches.Just compare thundering Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC with prissy dried-stick predecessor Dominic Grieve.Grieve is busy sabotaging Brexit. Cox finds ways to make it work.He is now “marking Number Ten’s homework” on Mrs May’s wretched Northern Ireland “backstop”.Some even tip him as a dark horse in the leadership stakes.There is one other big change needed at the heart of Britain’s Brexit team.Our next PM must have a new EU negotiator.Nobody could be worse than Olly Robbins, already reportedly eyeing up a £m-a-year golden parachute into a top City job.Lelong Europhile Robbins has led Mrs May into so many disastrous EU traps — especially her humiliation in Salzburg — he is often cast as an EU “double agent”.It was Robbins who told EU negotiator Michel Barnier that Britain might stay indefinitely in “transition” while the fantasy Northern Ireland backstop was sorted out.And pay £bn more on top of the £bn ransom for the privilege.The idea that Robbins is the “EU’s man in Whitehall” is not such a stretch when you consider his Jeremy Corbyn-style applause for Communist Russia.Kremlin leaders, he told fellow Oxford students in , “changed Russia from a backward peasant autocracy, despised by the West, into a technological giant at whom the world cowered in fear for half a century.”Everyone is entitled to youthful naivety.But can anyone imagine Olly Robbins fighting our corner for EU democracy and accountability, let alone the referendum verdict of .m Brexit-voting Brits SAUDI Arabia’s rulers must be really annoyed with dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.This elderly trouble maker walked alone into his country’s Turkish consulate knowing he might never emerge alive.He was clearly looking for trouble.Once inside, using his bare hands, he attacked a gang of  innocent Saudi torturers who had just flown in for a couple of hours’ holiday armed only with a bone saw and a hypodermic syringe.Then, to the embarrassment of kindly Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, he went and hid his own body.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit finish line in sight
story: Has it been a good day or a bad day for me  Am I up or down “How are YOU doing Prime Minister ” one journalist asked me recently. I didn’t reply at the time but I’m going to give Sun readers the answer now – and it’s very simple.None of this is about me. It’s all about you.That’s why, when I’m confronted with tough choices during the Brexit negotiations, I don’t think about what the implications are for me. Instead, I ask myself what it means for you, for your family and for the whole of the United Kingdom.Am I bringing back control of your money, your borders and your laws Am I protecting your jobs and making sure nothing gets in the way of our brilliant entrepreneurs and small businesses Am I protecting the integrity of the United Kingdom And, above all, am I delivering the Brexit that the people of this country so clearly voted for I need to be able to answer “Yes” to every one of these questions.Andthat means there are some dficult days in Brussels, well that’s just something I have to deal with.Because the Brexit talks are not about me or my personal fortunes. They’re about the national interest – and that means making the right choices, not the easy ones.Inevitably, that will take time. Brexit is the UK’s biggest constitutional change for generations. Unpicking more than  years of treaties, agreements and laws would be a challenge under any circumstances and, as no country has ever left the EU before, it’s not asthere’s an instruction manual for those either side of the negotiating table to follow.I know it can seem like the talks are never-ending, and that many of you have been frustrated by the endless back and forth on technical points – I certainly feel that way sometimes too.But with five months to go until we leave the EU, we have already reached agreement on the vast majority of our exit deal.What became clear at last week’s meeting in Brussels is that the very last stages of the talks are going to be the hardest of all.This includes dealing with the so-called “backstop”: making sure that, no matter what our new relationship with Europe looks like, there will be no hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.I’ve been very clear that this must be achieved without creating any kind of border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK – doing so would undermine our precious Union and put at risk the hard-won peace.So I am working closely with my counterparts in Europe to explore every possible solution to the border issue.Does that mean I think this negotiation will get tougher before we reach our goal  YesDo I have some long and dficult days ahead  I’m sure I do.But what I’m thinking about is not how hard it all is today.I’m thinking about the prize that lies before us tomorrow about the great opportunities the Government will help open up for you once we clear the last few hurdles.As we enter the final, crucial phase of the talks there will undoubtedly be some unexpected challenges to which we must rise.But the finish line is in sight. And I am more determined than ever that we will get there together, with a Brexit deal that’s right for you, right for your family and right for our country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which could lead to tooth discolouration.As nicotine is a vasocon-strictor, it limits blood flow in oral tissue, which can cause gum disease and bad breath.As time goes on, I am reading new research which proves vaping has a negative effect on health.To what extent, only time will tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teen asks how to burn cd
story: Before the days of streaming apps, music fans would assemble their favourite tracks onto CDs - a foreign concept to the younger generation these days.So when a teenager tweeted about the concept of CDs being burned it sparked a huge reaction.She wrote on Twitter: Maybe its just the generation Z in me but how did people burn CDs Like how did you just get a blank CD and put songs on it Thankfully one kind user explained the apparently ancient process.However most social media users took the opportunity to point out how old the tweet made them feel.One jokingly replied: All my hair turned grey reading this tweet.Another said: Part of me wants to explain how I used a blank cassette tape to record songs off the radio when I was a kid but I dont think Ill have time because theyve already lowered my casket into the hole and theyre shoveling dirt onto me at a truly frightening speed.A third user wrote: We would wait for a full moon and throw a blank CD into a giant bonfire and dance around it while chanting the titles of the songs we wanted on it.The final product would be sitting on top of the ashes after the flames went out.

title: theresa may supporters brexit love in
story: The PM was forced to rip up her schedule to address all ministers and backbenchers at a tense meeting of the party’s  Committee.Furious Brexiteers had billed the showdown as a final reckoning with her, with one even suggesting she should “bring her own noose”.But in what MPs dubbed a carefully coordinated operation by her whips, Mrs May was greeted with cheers and desk banging which continued through out the -minute meeting.And No was confident that Mrs May had done enough to see off the threat of a no confidence vote in her this week.One Brexiteer MP, Michael Fabricant insisted the PM had won the room over, emerging to say: “It’s not Daniella in the Lion’s Den, it’s a petting zoo in there.“It was a love in. Everybody was saying we need unity.”The PM spelled out to the room why she was pursuing a softer Brexit vision, warning that the referendum decision to leave the EU could have “consequences”.One MP told The Sun: “She said that we will be able to look voters in the eye and say we have honoured our commitment to uphold the referendum.“But she also said it’s the job of government to make sure that whatever Brexit we end up with, we will protect the economy from the cosequences.”Home Secretary Sajid Javid told The Sun that it was a “solid performance” that “will put to bed once and for all that she is the person to lead us”.But other Tory MPs branded the meeting “totally stage managed” with Whips planted to bang on the doors to make the applause from inside seem louder.One Leave-backing MP told The Sun that Mrs May’s pitch “wasn’t great”, adding: “She hasn’t won me over”.Some of the PM’s biggest critics, including former Tory leader IDS, stayed away altogether.Another senior Brexiteer backbencher said: “It was your standard  meeting, tightly controlled and designed for one thing - to give the leader a good show”.Most of the questions aimed at the PM were supportive, with MPs urging loyalty.But Brexit backer Andrew Bridgen tackled Mrs May directly on her handling of the negotiations on what concessions she had won from Brussels.As the PM began to reel off what she saw as wins on Citizens Rights, the ECJ and the transition period, MPs broke into applause in a bid to shore her up against her fiercest critics.Brexiteer Nadine Dorries also repeated her call for a change of leader after leaving the room.More Cabinet isions emerged yesterday when it emerged that Energy minister Claire Perry had made a thinly veiled dig at Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt for taking a position on Brexit just to further his leadership hopes.Ms Perry’s attack came during a meeting of the PM’s top table in No on Tuesday.Last night Theresa May was urged to back a FIVE-DAY debate on her final Brexit deal – where MPs would have the ability to consider alternatives before voting on the PM’s agreement.Former Tory Attorney General Dominic Grieve said this would allow MPs to see the scale of Commons support for other options such as a Norway-style deal before the crunch vote.Trying to avoid debate on alternatives would “be both wrong, and,I may add, I think it would be a very big mistake”.Today Environment Secretary Michael Gove will introduce the Fisheries Bill in Parliament – promising Britain is on the way to “taking back control of our waters”.The legislation will end the automatic right of EU vessels to fish in UK waters and proposing powers to ensure the UK can set its own fishing quotas.An Ipsos MORI poll yesterday revealed growing pessimism amongst the British public on Mrs May’s chances of getting a good deal.We are wary of it lasting a day beyond . Dragging us into another EU budget cycle wouldn’t just mean chipping in another few billion for bureaucrats to squander — it also risks the UK being roped in to the whole six-year cycle.If the PM has any hope of getting a deal through Parliament, the transition must have a legally-binding end date.Anything less would be the definition of a bad deal — and no deal is better than a bad deal.Three-quarters now say they lack confidence in her - %, up from % last month.A former Cabinet Minister declared Theresa May could be gone within a YEAR.Europhile Tory Nicky Morgan said she was absolutely behind the PM - for now.But she told ITVs Peston: I do think we will probably, in the course of the next  months, we will be looking for a new leader.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince harry meghan markle tonga fiji latest
story: The Duchess wowed in green in Fiji and stunned in red after a mid-air outfit change before meeting royalty in the Pacic island nation this morning.She looked amazing in her Self Portrait dress, blue stilettos and black clutch bag - but fans noticed a stray tag hanging from the hem.The Duke and Duchess took a -minute flight to Tonga, on day ten of their South Pacic tour, and she made sure her wardrobe matched the colour of the national flag.The couple landed at Fuaamotu Airport in the countrys capital and were welcomed by Princess Angelika Latufuipeka and dancers in grass skirts.Meghan, who was forced to cut duties short after a security scare yesterday, looked refreshed after a night alone with Harry on a private luxury island.The Duchess had a very minor wardrobe malThe royal couple then walked the red carpet, accompanied by traditional entertainment from Pelehake villagers.Airport staff met them holding a sign saying Welcome Harry and Meghan, and waving Union Jacks.They were then escorted off to Consular House for a private audience with King Tupou VI and Queen Nanasipauu, where they attended an official reception and dinner, featuring traditional entertainment.Upon arrival, Meghan glowed in a stunning floor- white gown with detailing on the shoulders.The loving couple hold hands after leaving the plane in TongaThe Duchess smiles as she accepts flowers from a girl in traditional dressSchoolchildren had been given the day off and lined the streets from the airport to the capital of Nukualofa, waving flags and cheering as the convoy made the -minute journey.The royal pair first appeared at Fijis Nadi Airport this morning, where they unveiled a statue of SAS hero Sgt Talaiasi Labalaba.The super-solder died in battle after holding off  rebels on his own.Meghan looked classy in a green £, Jason Wu dress, which showed off her growing baby bump, and tall black heels.Prince Harry looked dapper in a grey suit and military medalsHarry shouts Bula! and claps three times in Fijian tradition as he drinks Kava - a mild sedative made from powdered yagona rootHarry looked dapper in a grey suit and wore military medals as he honoured Sgt Talaiasi, who was killed in the Battle of Mirbat in .He was stationed in Oman with eight SAS soldiers on a secret assignment, codenamed Operation Jaguar.When their hideout was ambushed, he sprinted - under enemy fire - to a heavy artillery gun which usually requires three men to operate.Despite grave bullet wounds and being soaked in blood, he single-handedly held off  fighters for six hours - long enough for reinforcements to arrive.Harry unveils a statue of SAS hero Sergeant Talaiasi LabalabaAfter the ceremony, the president of Fiji, Major General Jioji Konrote, thanked the royal couple for their visit and congratulated them on their baby news.Harry also spoke, saying he and Meghan were leaving with special memories of your beautul country and look forward to ing in the future.Yesterday, Meghan was whisked out of a Fijian street market amid a security scare.Video shows her being led out of the building flanked by her new female head of security and a Fijian security chief.The Duchess has pulled out of a number of engagements this week, blaming tiredness and the toll of her pregnancy.Last night the pair spent a night together on the isolated island of Vatua, described as one of the worlds most beautul places.

title: saudi prince jokes lebanese prime minister kidnapping
story: MBS as he is popularly known quipped that Prime Minister Saad al-Hariri was free to leave Saudi Arabia following his detention in the kingdom last year.Bin Salman, attending an international investment conference in Riyadh, said: Prime Minister Saad is staying in the kingdom for two days so I hope you don’t spread rumours that he was kidnapped.Hariri, sitting beside the crown prince, took part in the humour as the audience laughed. “With all my freedom,” he said.Hariri, who has Saudi citizenship, was summoned to the kingdom a year ago, briefly detained and compelled to resign as prime minister in a speech read out on television from Saudi until France intervened to free him.The Crown Princes joshing comes amid mounting global pressure to provide a satisfactory answers to questions over the killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.Khashoggi, a prominent critic of MBSs regime, was killed in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on nd October.Bin Salman said justice will prevail and the culprits punished.Hours earlier US President Donald Trump told reporters that the crown prince bore ultimate responsibility for the operation that led to Khashoggis killing.The kingdom has survived other crises, including the fallout of the short-lived kidnapping of Hariri.Hariri was verbally humiliated and beaten, according to eight Saudi, Arab and Western diplomatic sources.

title: meps golden handshake pay off
story: Our euro MPs will receive generous “transitional allowances” in March to cushion the blow of forgoing their bumper £, a year salaries.All UK representatives will get a basic rate of at least six months’ pay, with senior ones pocketing upwards of £,.On top of that, MEPs get a £, lump sum to cover the cost of shutting down their offices and have their transport back home to the UK paid for.The total bill for golden handshakes has been estimated at around £. million, with British taxpayers picking up part of the tab.The revelations emerged after a meeting at the EU Parliament in Strasbourg on Tuesday where eurocrats debriefed departing Brits on their severance pay.All MEPs who have served more than a year will receive a payout equivalent to one month’s salary for every year they have served.That means former Ukip leader Nigel Farage, who has been MEP for the South East for  years, is set to receive around £,.Meanwhile the most recent intake from , who have served just four years, will still be entitled to a minimum of six months of their salary.Those over the age of  immediately start claiming their EU pension, which is worth .% of their monthly salary, instead of taking transition cash.According to a note seen by The Sun, euro MPs are also entitled to “reimbursement of two-thirds of the costs incurred as a result of sickness, pregnancy or the birth of a child”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: freedom of the press sun says gagging claims
story: Yesterday, it was revealed that the Dailyhas been stopped from revealing the name of a prominent businessman who — on at least five occasions — has used non-disclosure agreements and hush money to silence allegations against him.Is it in the public interest for a loaded businessman to be able to silence the Press by spending half a million quid on legal proceedings Or for the public to know what he’s been accused of, and paid handsome sums to keep it quiet Ask yourself this:a member of your family was applying for a job working for him, wouldn’t you want to know The #MeToo scandal showed just how far powerful figures will go to keep their victims schtum. But it’s not just Harvey Weinstein and Hollywood.Over the past year, we’ve seen the High Court impose serious reporting restrictions on police arrests and a bid by Press-hating tycoon Max Mosley to wipe his fascist past out of history citing the ‘right to be forgotten’.It will be you, the public, who lose outthe rich and powerful stop us doing our job.GIVE us a date, Prime Minister.No, not for your departure. But for the end of the transition period.We are wary of it lasting a day beyond .If the PM has any hope of getting a deal through Parliament, the transition must have a legally-binding end date.Anything less would be the definition of a bad deal — and no deal is better than a bad deal.DOES John Bercow have no shame With every day he sits in the Speaker’s chair he discredits Parliament.His refusal to take allegations of bullying and harassment seriously is an embarrassment at the heart of our democracy.Parliament has a ready-made replacement for this rhino-hided oaf in Lindsay Hoyle — respected across the House.Bercow must go. Now.TURKISH supremo Recep Erdogan can spare us the holier than thou act on human rights.What happened to Jamal Khashoggi at the hands of the Saudis is disgraceful.
