title: photo ghost woman grave
story: Pauline Day said her teams electric energy meters were going haywire when the haunting pictures were taken at a graveyard in West Yorkshire.They show a mysterious mist forming in front of the camera as it takes a shape that resembles an older woman with her arm extended.Rob Crabtree, , took the snaps of the gravestone in Todmorden Unitarian Church.Rob, from Bradford, believes the final photo shows Sarah Agnes, who died aged  in  and is buried in the plot with her husband, James Davenport.He said: “We went out into the graveyard – it’s a real spooky place – and I took a few photos, and that’s one of the pictures that I caught.“If you read the gravestone there’s a lady buried there who was  and there’s also a lady that was , and I think it was her.“I just got a feeling that it was her and the face looked older.”He added: “Everybody can see it straight away that it’s a lady’s face. I’ve shown it to quite a few people and they’ve all made it out straight away.”Rob, who says the churchyard wasn’t even misty at the time, recalls feeling drawn to that particular headstone.“I was drawn to it definitely,” he said. “I took pictures of one or two other gravestones but that one I took quite a few of.“I did get the feeling I was in touch with someone.”Pauline Day, who organised the charitable ghost hunt, said she had sensed a spirit at the graveside.“I was calling out to her,” she said. “l could sense that she was there because our electric energy meters were going off.”“Then at break time – at am in the morning – we all went through our cameras to see what we had got and, to our surprise, one of my guests captured this picture.“We were all elated.”The church itself dates back to  and remained open until , though it is still licensed for weddings.

title: theresa may full scale no deal brexit plans
story: The Prime Minister will hit go on detailed emergency plans to get everyone ready for not securing an agreement in November, which would see current Commons business ditched.If theres not an agreement on the cards by then, ministers will be forced to put forward a series of new bills to get passed by March , when Britain officially leaves the EU.At least four are needed to guarantee the rights of EU citizens and on fishing beforehand.And thousands of bits of other laws have to be drafted too to make sure our laws are fit for purpose after we leave the bloc.Ministers have been deliberating for months when to push the go button on full-scale No Deal plans, The Times reported.Talks are still deadlocked with the EU over the Irish border, but both sides have said they are still hopeful a deal can be sealed.That will likely be signed off at Decembers EU Council meeting, but an emergency summit in Brussels could be called at any time, both sides have said.Today Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab told MPs in the Commons: We are striving for a good deal with our partners, but we will be ready for No Deal.He said there was a risk of failing to sign off an agreement, especiallythe EU engage in a deliberately transient approach.And he warned of the French deliberately directing a ‘go slow’ approach by supporting a ersion of the flow to more amenable ports in other countries.To get ready he said that , letters had been sent already to customs users, and , to businesses on how to prepare. technical notices have already been sent to get the country as ready as possible for whatever outcome.Chancellor Philip Hammond has set aside billions of pounds to for emergency plans.If the No Deal plans get put into action, , businesses will be told by Christmas they have to register for customs dutiesthey sell within the EU.And the Department of Health will be expected to sign contacts to stockpile medicines in case of any border disruption.One senior government figure told the paper that cabinet had decided that the government needed to “crack on”.We’re about to introduce no-deal legislation very, very soon,” they said.We have to crack on because it will all need royal assent before we leave. Then there will be an awful lot to discuss and it will concentrate minds. Obviously we don’t want to upset the negotiations but the clock is ticking and it will get harder and harder the later we leave it.PRO-EU party bosses are today lobbying Michel Barnier to try and convince him Brexit should be reversed.Leaders from the Lib Dems, Greens, SNP and Plaid Cymru have travelled to Brussels for a meeting with the EUs top Brexit envoy.They promised to push him to try and keep Britain in the single market and customs union - and make the case for a so-called peoples vote.Lib Dem chief Vince Cable said: “Our ‘unholy alliance’ has provided a sensible counterpoint to the hard-line Brexiteers who have pushed the Conservatives and Labour’s frontbench into senseless and fudged positions.It is vital that Michel Barnier and the European Commission know that there is another view in Parliament, one that has cross-party support and that can get the EU and the UK out of this mess.The SNPs Ian Blackford added: While the UK Government clearly still has no plan to break the Brexit impasse, and Labour fail to act as an effective opposition, it has been left to the unofficial opposition to speak up for a deal that would protect jobs and livelihoods.The Remainer politicians vowed to continue pushing Mr Barnier and other Eurocrats.But a damning report yesterday said that major projects getting our borders ready for No Deal might not be ready in time.The National Audit Office’s alarming investigation found the Government faces a race against time to replace critical IT systems, boost Border Force staffing levels and build new infrastructure to track goods in time for our departure next March.  out of  were at risk of not being done before we leave.It was revealed earlier this week that ministers will step up No Deal planning - with weekly updates to the cabinet.Mrs May told MPs that a deal was  per cent done, with the remaining five per cent focusing just on Northern Ireland issues.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gold leaf poppies remembrance day
story: One in six poppies will have “-” printed in gold on the green leaf.It is part of the organisation’s campaign to get people to buy and wear a poppy to pay their respects to those who sacriced their lives during the Great War.The Legion has launched its biggest poppy appeal to date, which is less than three weeks before Remembrance Sunday.The special gold leaf poppy isn’t the only addition to this year’s all-important campaign.Another poppy is also being launched today and it is even rarer than the gold leaf poppy.It is called the “khadi” poppy and instead of being made from paper is it made from the same linen that was worn by Mahatma Gandhi.Not many have been produced, about ,, and they have been made to honour the , Indian Army troops who lost their lives fighting for the Crown during World War I.The Legion launches their campaign today by also unveiling  installations across the UK to highlight the legacy of the Great War.The installations are a six-metre high poppy with red threads stretching across the floor featuring messages from the World War I generation and it is to highlight how their legacy is woven into the fabric of the UK.This year is especially important as this year’s Poppy Appeal wants to encourage people to highlight reasons to say “Thank You” to the Great War generation.The Royal British Legion’s Director of Fundraising, Claire Rowclfe said: “We thought it poignant in the year we mark the end of the First World War centenary to launch a special version of our paper poppy for the Poppy Appeal, something we have never done before.There are  million in the  million we distribute during the Remembrance period, and we look forward to seeing those who find one wearing their special poppy with pride.”Prime Minister Theresa May is set to help launch this year’s campaign.You can make a one-off donation online, set up a regular gt or even leave a sum in your will.You can donate by calling    or by sending a text message.To donate £, you can text POPPY to .Or to donate £, text POPPY to .You can also print off a donation form to send money in the post.The Legion hopes to raise £million this year.Poppies were first worn after American academic Monia Michael was inspired by Canadian medic Lt-Col John McCrae’s poem In Flanders Fields.In  she crafted and sold red silk poppies and the idea took off after coming to England.The first Poppy Appeal was held in , which was the founding year of The Royal British Legion.The poppy is a symbol of remembrance and hope and it is the colour red because of the flower’s natural colour.Some people wear a white poppy that is sold by the Peace Pledge Union as a symbol of peace and pacism and show their opposition to war.The Legion’s annual Poppy Appeal comes as Cambridge University Students’ Union tried to scrap the mention of poppies in the university’s plans for Remembrance Day.In an initial poll,  of  representatives voted to remove the mention of poppies and “British war veterans”.The motion was debated and eventually defeated.

title: driver mows down a family of ducks moments after a woman tried to help them cross a road
story: Footage shows two nine ducklings and their parents attempting to get their brood across a two lane road in Queenstown, New Zealand.A woman in a purple raincoat stopped to warn drivers to slow down as the little flock tried to get to water on the other side of the street.The family has two close-calls with cars which ignored the warning sign, while a vehicle in the opposite lane yields to the request and slows on approach, the NZ Herald reported.As the woman in purple makes her way on to the road, attempting to heard the ducklings out of harm’s way.But seconds after stepping to safety herself, a careless driver in a red car speeds straight through the family of birds.Video of the distressing incident surfaced after Rolf Liechti lodged a complaint with local police demanding justice for the nine ducklings and their parents.Unfortunately, he never heard back from the police handling his inquiry.  .Rolf said the mother died in the accident, as did one of her ducklings.He went on to say that without their mother, it was likely all the other ducklings died shortly thereafter.Rolf added: “Whenever we see them [ducks] we always stop the traffic and help them across the road ... everyone does ... because they go across the road to the creek.“We even had signs up there last year after someone ran over them, but this guy just didnt even seem to give a s***, either that or he was on the phone or something or wasnt looking, who knows.A spokesperson from the police force admits they did choose not to take the complaint any further, but say as far as they were aware, no crime was committed.“It didnt appear from the information provided during that call that an offence had been committed so no further action was taken.”

title: meghan markle prince harry fiji private island
story: The £,-a-day getaway saw the newlyweds enjoy secluded beaches and crystal clear waters on the idyllic Vatua Private Islands, about an hour east of the Fijian capital Suva.The mini-break came on the couple’s third and final night in Fiji, which the parents-to-be chose to spend alone.While there are no official prices displayed for the private island of Vatua, it is believed to cost around £, per night .The island paradise boasts three secluded beachside villas, which have been meticulously constructed using local materials.With -acres of private land for explorers to take advantage of, visitors will be spoilt for choice between the expansive beaches, crystal clear waters and even a small golf course.One night at a villa on the private island costs around £,The mum-to-be, who revealed she is waking at .am during the royal tour to do yoga, will have also had the chance to indulge in the island’s private classes.Visitors to the islands can snorkel in the turquoise waters of the coral reef or go fishing for marlin, tuna and wahoo in the resorts -foot trawler.Vatua has two restaurants to choose from, where guests are served freshly caught seafood and organic vegetables grown on the island’s farms.The couples trip has been described by some royal watchers as the ideal babymoon, with the royals expecting their first child in the Spring.Tourism Minister Faiyaz Koya described the island as a paradise, adding: “Vatua is one of those islands you will not forget.“It showcases the Fijian spirit and what we have as Fijian people.“Its absolutely beautul. Stunning.“They would have enjoyed themselves.”Meghan and Harry are now  days into their -day long trip taking in Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga.It is their first official overseas tour since their wedding in May, with the Duchess’ pregnancy announcement coming as they touched down in Sydney earlier this month.While Meghan has wowed the world with her grace and charm, her wardrobe has been the highlight for fashion lovers around the world.Wearing a staggering  outfits in just ten days, the Duchess has chosen a range of designers that pay tribute to both her new British home and her host nations.She has also subtly paid tribute to her mother in law, Princess Diana, by donning items of jewellery that once belonged to her.However, she made a rare fashion faux-pas on arrival in Tonga after forgetting to remove a dress tag following a mid-air flight change.While Meghan looked amazing in her Self Portrait dress that matched the colours of Tonga’s flag, fans noticed a stray tag hanging from the hem.While some claimed it was a price tag, others believed it to be a care label that had been accidentally overlooked.

story: Betsy Reyes of Oklahoma City, USA says Princess sneaks out at night and lingers outside her local fast food restaurant in the hope customers will feed her.In a Facebook post that has since gone viral, Reyes shared a photo of Princess saying: “If you see my dog @ the McDonald’s on shields, quit feeding her fat ass bc she don’t know how to act  be leaving the house all the time to go walking to McDonald’s at night.“She’s not even a stray dog.”Reyes decided that sharing the image on Facebook was simply not enough, and drove to catch the pet in the act at her local McDonalds on Monday night, reported Time.She caught her dog waiting to bed fed by other customers. title: picture deer hiding forest
story: The colour of the little fawns coat blends perfectly with the background keeping it camouflaged and safe from predators.The little deer was unwittingly caught on camera by photograher Ingo Gerlach, , who failed to spot it as he was looking at two stags rutting in the distance.It was only later that his pictures revealed the hidden animal nestled close to a clump of tree stumps and fallen trees just feet away from him.Ingo said: The young stag really adapted well to his surroundings which is why he is so hard to spot.I couldnt believe it when I realised the young deer had been right in front of me.He must have been hiding from the older deer who can be quite aggressive when in rut.The young stag was snapped in front of a forest in the Sauerland region in Germany.The rut is a part of the mating season where male deer have a large increase in testosterone which leads them to be more aggressive and sometimes violent.

title: alan sugar calls second brexit referendum first vote did not count
story: Repeating his demands for Boris Johnson and Michael Gove to be thrown in jail, the businessman and Apprentice host said the public need to be given a say in the final Brexit deal.But bizarrely he also slammed the idea of re-running the last referendum, saying that would be a complete farce to have another crack at the whip.In a debate in the House of Lords this afternoon he told peers: I seriously believe the public were misled and for that reason I support the idea of a vote by the public to agree the final negotiated terms.Lord Sugar said the Peoples Vote campaign, which saw , march through London last weekend to try and overturn Brexit, sounded like I dont like the outcome, so Id like another bite of the cherry to seeit can be reversed.But most campaigners who are advocating another referendum dont want us to leave at all, and insist that Remain should be on the ballot in another vote.Lord Sugar said he felt the public were misled in forming a decision to leave and that only deciding on the future terms would solve the problem.He arrogantly claimed thathe had appeared as part of TV debates as he was asked to by David Cameron who knows, maybe that would have swung the vote.Brits should be explained all the options in another vote, which would spell out the pros and cons.But immediately Brexiteers hit back at his demands.One wrote on Twitter: The people voted for Brexit. Ive had enough of voting.Lord Sugar said his business experience meant he had sympathy for Theresa May for having to negotiate but not be able to say how its all going.And common sense must prevail that at least we get a trade deal, he predicted.I do hope and believe that a rabbit will be pulled out of the hat shortly.

title: uk would pay 11bn a year on debt interest under labours sky high spending plans enough for 400000 nurses
story: John McDonnell wants to spend as much as £trillion more on reversing austerity and seizing rail, water and energy firms.But only half of the extra spending is to be funded by higher taxes or cuts where - meaning the national debt could rise by more than £billion over a decade.That would see the countrys bill for debt interest rise by £.billion every year.Andinterest rates rose because lenders began to doubt Britains ability to pay, the amount spent on servicing the debt would soar even higher.£.billion would be enough money to pay for nearly , nurses, or more than , police officers.Overall the debt accrued under Labours plans would add up to £, for every family in the country.Tory chairman Brandon Lewis blasted: “Just like last time Labour’s reckless plans would undo all the hard work of the British people and result in more debt, higher taxes and fewer jobs.“Labour’s eye-watering unfunded spending would let debt spiral out of control and see more taxpayers money spent on debt repayments, rather than on public services.The partys plans include ramping up spending on childcare and building new homes.Labour also wants to nationalise the railways, water companies and the Royal Mail as part of a programme of huge capital spending.A spokesman said: This is complete fiction from the Tories. It’s a mangled mess of wildly inaccurate numbers from a Conservative party which couldnt even cost its own manesto at the last election.Labour set out our fully costed proposals at the last election and well do the same for the next election - which cant come soon enough.Mr McDonnell, the Shadow Chancellor, today claimed Philip Hammond is set to unveil a trick or treat Budget when he announces tax and spending plans next week.He attacked the Tories for claiming austerity is coming to an end, saying: All we have had is a few random announcements on NHS and social care funding, plus lting the housing cap and a fuel freeze.Mr McDonnell also revealed he has suffered facial injuries after tripping over a pile of rubbish left near his home by fly-tippers.He said: I came out of the Parliamentary Labour Party meeting on Monday, which was very good, went home, got off the bus and Im rushing home, its pretty dark and someone has fly-tipped at the end of my road.So I missed it and I literally landed on my face. title: moment squirrel found stuck fence testicles
story: The creature’s painful experience was captured on video by a stunned – yet sympathetic – bloke, who admitted: “I’ve never seen anything like this in my le.”David Prince was taking a stroll with his son on Monday when he found the unfortunate rodent clinging desperately to a wooden barrier.Looking closer, he was shocked to see the squirrel had somehow managed to wedge his nether regions firmly between two separate .In video footage, the squirrel can be seen frantically trying to turn around and escape, clawing desperately at the fence .His paws can also be seen trying to free his trapped testes – but they were too swollen to sht easily.Prince, from Madison in Mississippi, said: “I’ve never seen anything like this in my le.“My son saw it and came and got me. I’ve no idea how long he was stuck.“Judging by his energy level I would think not too long.”Moving to the other side of the fence to take a closer glimpse, Prince can be heard saying to his son while videoing the animals eye-watering plight: “That poor guy.That is no kidding, this squirrel’s balls are stuck in the fence.Approaching the firmly wedged critter, he adds: “Hey you, you got some issues going on there “You got some problems buddy “Oh poor guy, he does not look too happy.”Prince decided to try and rescue the animal, explaining later: “I used a stick to pry his nuts up to the top of the fence.“I broke one stick trying, and we also tried to pry the fence apart.“He ran off into the bushes and we havent seen him since.”

title: hawaiian island disappeared hurricane climate change
story: Satellite images have confirmed that the -acre East Island in the French Frigate shoals has been entirely erased following Hurricane Walaka earlier this month.The tiny island, which was around half a mile long and  feet wide, was a key habitat for the critically endangered Hawaiian monk seal, endangered green sea turtle, as well as several species of seabirds and tiger sharks.Before disappearing, Hawaii’s East and Trig islands accounted for  per cent of the monk seal pups born at French Frigate Shoals.The category three hurricane, with wind speeds of up to mph, came within  miles of the west of the island in early October .East Island was the second-largest islet in the French Frigate Shoals, an enormous protected marine area in the north-western Hawaiian Islands around  miles from Honolulu.Dr Chip Fletcher was one of seven researchers forced to evacuate from French Frigate Shoals before the storm struck.The professor of earth sciences at the University of Hawaii told the Honolulu Civil Beat: I had a holy **** moment, thinking Oh my God, its gone.Its one more chink in the wall of the network of ecosystem ersity on this planet that is being dismantled.Dr Fletcher and his colleagues were in the process of researching East Island through drone videos and taking samples of sand and corals to ascertain the age of the island and gauge its future prospects in the face of climate change.He said: “The island was probably one to two thousand years old and we were only there in July, so for it to be lost right now is pretty bad luck.”Officials will not know the extent of the damage until they can get out to the remote location to investigate.It is also unclearEast Island will ever resurface.An islet named Whale-Skate Island, also once an important habitat for Hawaiian monk seals, vanished from French Frigate Shoals almost  years ago and has not reappeared.This island suffered considerably from erosion starting in the s and by the late s, it was completely submerged.

title: women military roles apply any special forces
story: Gavin Williamson revealed that, as of today, women already serving in the Army are able to transfer into infantry roles # including the Special Forces.Mr Williamson said: #Women have led the way with exemplary service in the armed forces for over  years, working in a iety of specialist and vital roles.#So I am delighted that from today, for the first time in its history, our armed forces will be determined by ability alone and not gender.#Opening all combat roles to women will not only make the armed forces a more modern employer but will ensure we recruit the right person for the right role.#Those not currently serving will be able to apply for infantry roles in December of this year, with new recruits starting basic training in April .The historic day was marked at a land power demonstration on Salisbury Plain, involving some of the first women to join the Royal Armoured Corps.The Defence Secretary also confirmed women are now able to apply join the Royal Marines, with selection starting before the end of this year.The Royal Armoured Corps was the first ground close combat branch to open its doors in November  to female soldiers and officers, followed by the RAF Regiment in September .Since November  the Army has about  women either serving or being trained to join the Royal Armoured Corps, with a number of personnel already being deployed in their new role to Estonia and Oman.A Ministry of Defence spokesman said: #While the military does not necessarily expect large numbers of women to apply for ground close combat roles, the changes are aimed at creating opportunities for iniduals from all backgrounds and making the most of their talents.#By making all branches and trades of the military open to everyone, regardless of their gender, the armed forces are building on their reputation of being a leading equal opportunities employer.#

title: a coppers copper count scotland
story: NewsA coppers copper - the Count of Scotland Yard Herbert Hannam who helped send a double killer to the hangmans nooseHerbert Hannam was the policeman who helped send the man behind double murder to the gallows and forged a career as a tough law enforcerShareCommentsByStephen Wade:,  OCT NewsHannam was known as The Count of Scotland Yard "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTop coppers, as well as lowly constables, are equally tried and tested in a courtroom. Legal process and smart performers in the drama of a trial will catch them out. But Bert Hannam, in his long career, would match any barrister, and survive cross-examination with a flair and panache that won him admirers, but also made some enemies. It was March,  in Number One court at the Old Bailey and the man in the dock was a family doctor, being tried for murder. The previous year was free of hangings, as the pressure for reform and for abolition of the death penalty was gaining momentum, but now here was John Bodkin Adams , long-serving doctor in Eastbourne, being potentially the first person hanged after the year when the public executioner was rested from his duties.The police officer charged with the task of gathering evidence against Adams was one of the Yard’s top detectives, Bert Hannam. The sleuth and his team were faced with the task of crossing swords with a brilliant defence barrister, Geoffrey Lawrence, and Lawrence has fastened on one meeting of Hannam with Adams which was, as the detective stated, a ‘chance meeting’ at which searching questions had been asked.  Lawrence had already made the medical experts called by the prosecution look hopelessly inept, and Bart knew he was in for a tough time. He was cool, controlled and ready with factual details which explained away the chance meeting as nothing sinister or threatening to the doctor.Hannam, ‘The Count of Scotland Yard’ came through and held his own with a brilliant legal brain. The Yard had had learned this the hard way. Starting as a young copper in the late twenties, he worked his way through the ranks during the war and proved his mettle in cases of theft, fraud and corruption. He was not noticed by the press though, until the notorious Teddington Towpath murders in the summer of  when the world could talk of nothing  but the coronation and the royal family. Alfred Whiteway had raped and killed two young women on the towpath, and Hannam found himself leading a murder investigation, after playing second fiddle to other men, gather valuable experience and acquiring the confidence and the professional skills involved in dealing with serious crime. He got his man, but again, his main obstacle was a courtroom tussle, brought out when it was known that a constable had taken away the murder weapon in the police car, back to his home. Bert Hannam, by the time he faced the formidable Geoffrey Lawrence, was the man the Yard brought in to sort things out. In the Towpath murder trial there was an allegation from Whiteway that his confession had been forced from him.Hannam, the defence lawyer put it to Hannam that the confession was ‘completely manufactured’ and Hannam, unflustered and calm, said simply but with authority, ‘That is absolutely untrue.’ ‘The Count’ was a man with charisma.  He was meticulously concerned with his appearance, his manner and his confidence as a man who would inspire confidence and trust. When he went north to lead the investigation into the brutal murder of an aged shop-keeper in Halax, Emily Pye, the local paper was impressed and their account of him makes clear the power of the man’s presence, And in an interview with a reporter we have a brief instance of his matter-of –fact efficiency: The Scotland Yard chief... made a special appeal to Halax people for information about anyone who was not at home between  noon and three p.m. on Saturday. I know this sounds like an enormous task but I would like to see them all the same. This was a most terrible crime. The woman was really brutally attacked. Bert Hannam was a man who cultivated the habit of having men working with him who could be trusted to absorb and apply his methods, and these were always carefully planned and discussed. He had learned from the best, and he had been compelled to conduct investigations in wartime, in the heart of the Blitz, where he made many friends working in the criminal justice system, including the brilliant Molly Lefebure, assistant to Dr Keith Simpson, the Home Office pathologist. He was not the most forthcoming person when faced with the curiosity of the media, and his arch-enemy was Percy Hoskins, chief crime reporter of The Express. Percy took against the extreme thoroughness of Bert’s gathering of evidence of Adams the higher echelons of the judiciary and leaders of the government were faced with the potential hanging of a family doctor and Hoskins began to see Bert’s determined and prolonged search for evidence as a witch-hunt against a man who was easing the passing of people near death.  One way or another, the victory in court, keeping Adams out of the death cell and from the end of a rope, had to happen. In an age when detectives were glamorous and beginning to appear on radio and television dramas, Bert Hannam merely got on with the job in hand and never succumbed to the vain courting of celebrity.He had that most valuable of detective capabilities: discretion. What is not widely known about the man is his participation in currency regulation investigation in the immediate post-war years. He was not merely an officer linked to murder cases far from it in fact, because he always acquired what we would now call a wide portfolio of expertise on his c.v. He learned fast and he understood that he was working at a time when police corruption was in the air as well as in the news. Even the fact that took part in enquiries regarding this corruption could have given him a tainted image. But he kept to professional actions and attitudes and pressed on with duties regardless of criticisms. In the s, when Britain was still slowly and painfully recovering from the deprivations and sufferings of the war, the police were gradually reformed and reorganised. New strategies of police training came along, to replace the Trenchard measures of the pre-war years, Bert Hannam became something of a consultant and mentor, and his son was to later become the man who ran the new college. The Hannam name was firmly placed in recent police history.

title: girl 4 saves mums life
story: NewsGirl, , saves mums le by calling  after finding her lying unconscious on kitchen floorIsabella Hibbert found and unlocked mum Chas mobile phone before ringing for an ambulance in Oldham - and then moving a chair to reach the front door keys to let paramedics inShareCommentsBySam YarwoodKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video isabella-calls--mum-collapses-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little girl has been hailed a hero after after finding her mum lying unconscious on the kitchen floor in the middle of the night and calling . Isabella Hibbert, who was only four years old at the time, managed to find and unlock mum Chas mobile phone before ringing for an ambulance. The youngster, now aged five, was able to give the call handler her address so they could send help. She also answered scary questions like is your mummy breathing  and is your mummy awake  clearly. The clever tot then dragged her little chair from the living room to the front door, so she could reach the keys to open it for the paramedics.She then rang her nana - again on Chas phone - to tell her what had happened, the Manchester Evening News reports. Cha, , from Oldham, was taken to hospital and has recovered from her ordeal but is still undergoing tests to find out what caused her to collapse. I dont remember much, all I remember is waking up on the kitchen floor surrounded by paramedics. I had been poorly during the day, I hadnt felt well, but it was nothing major. Isabella had been sleeping with me, and I must have gotten up and gone downstairs for a drink. She must have noticed I wasnt there and followed me down and found me on the floor. Clare Cattermole, the medical emergency dispatcher who took Isabellas call in August, described the schoolgirl as amazing. It was the first time Clare had ever taken a call from a young child, but she added that Isabella answered her questions better than most adults. She said: You dont expect to hear a young persons voice on the phone.  Ive had a few child callers before, but a parent will always take over the call. But when Isabella told me her mummy wasnt awake, I knew that wasnt going to happen this time. There are certain questions that we have to ask, and you have to make sure you bring them down to her age so she can follow. She engaged really well, she was amazing and is a real credit to her mum. She answered every question, better than most adults to be honest. Clare, based at the North West Ambulance Services Liverpool call centre, explained that sometimes when a call comes through it can give you an idea of where the caller is. But this wasnt the case with Chas phone, and Clare had no information as to where Isabella was. Had the little girl not known her address - which Cha says is down to a family joke they have with her auntie - then it could have taken a long time to trace the call and send help. She added: Its so important that kids know this information.  After I spoke to Isabella, I thought - would my kids have been able to do that  So when I got home I told them what to do so they would know what to do in an emergency. Isabella, who is in reception at East Crompton St James Primary School in Shaw, and Cha were reunited with Clare at NWAS Manchester call centre on Wednesday. They were given a tour before Isabella was presented with an Infant Le Saver award for her heroic actions. Cha, who works for GTD , says she had never had a conversation with her daughter about what to do in an emergency, but says she loves watching ambulance programmes and believes she must have picked it up from there, or by listening to her talking about her work. Im so proud of her, she added. I just dont think she realises how big what she did was.

title: jealous man bugged girlfriends bedroom
story: NewsJealous man bugged girlfriends bedroom and tracked her phone because he thought she was cheatingLee Jensen, , of Grimsby, also subjected Danielle Ames to body searchesShareCommentsByPeter CraigAbigail OLeary:,  OCT NewsA victim impact statement claimed Jensen repeatedly called her a tramp and sometimes spat at her "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA paranoid ex-Royal Marine bugged his girlfriends bedroom and carried out body searches on her because he thought she was cheating. Lee Jensen, , also installed a tracking device on girlfriend Danielle Amess mobile phone in his jealous bid to know where she was at all hours of the day. Jensen, from Grimsby, went on to send abusive text messages to Danielles manager accusing him of showing an interest in her.He was convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour at Grimsby Crown Court where he received a -month suspended sentence, reports Grimsby Live .Judge Simon Jack said: It must have been very degrading and distressing for her to be treated that way. You have recognised that what you have done was wrong by your guilty pleas.  Prosecuting Jeremy Evans said Danielle had known Jensen for around  months and an intimate relationship started around November last year. He said he lived at his home near Peoples Park in Grimsby and she lived at her home in the town. Mr Evans said: She describes how he behaved loving and gentlemanly towards her to begin with but then he began to accuse her of infidelity. She could not tolerate that and broke off the relationship. It resumed in February of this year but very quickly that behaviour began to deteriorate and spiral out of control. It had been a relationship that was working and she felt supported. But then he obtained the passwords to heraccounts and he was tracking her using her mobile phone. The court heard she obtained employment but had to stop work after a number of weeks after Jensen sent abusive text messages to her manager accusing him of showing an interest in her.  He wanted to know where she was at all hours of the day and constantly accused her of infidelity, said Mr Evans. He added: When she attempted to leave both homes, he would prevent her. The prosecutor said bugging devices were concealed under cushions in her bedroom by Jensen, so he could listen to her. He subjected her to body checks. He prevented her from visiting her own GP. After the relationship ended he made futile threats to burn her house down. Danielle sought accommodation at a Womens Refuge. But Jensen found out where it was an was seen repeatedly driving past it. Reading her Victim Impact Statement, Mr Evans said: She feels her le has been taken away from her. She has lost her independence, lost her employment and had her children taken from her. Because she lost her job she has not been able to pay rent and has had to move. He added: She said It is almost like he is an addiction that I cannot live without him. i am not the person I once was. i feel isolated and a shadow of my former self. He said he repeatedly called her a tramp and sometimes spat at her. For Jensen, Nigel Sloane said since his arrest in August he has been in prison on remand.  He said: It has given him time to reflect on what he has done and he tells me it has given him time to sort his head out.He added there was no contact with the complainant and there were no previous convictions against his client. Mr Sloane said his client suffered from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder from his service in the military both with the Army and Royal Navy. It does not give a reasonbut it is a factor. Judge Jack said Jensens stress disorder following his military service may have been a contributory factor in his paranoia. He ordered Jensen to undergo a rehabilitation requirement over  days and take part in a building better relationships programme. A restraining order not to contact Danielle was imposed for two years. A curfew from pm to am is in place for the next three months.

story: NewsPeople think Meghan Markle has given away her babys due date after spotting clue on her handBookies have even slashed the odds after royal fans noticed the potential giveawayShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video duchess-sussexs-fashion-story-far-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email All eyes are on Meghan Markle and Prince Harry this month after they dropped a pregnancy announcement at the start of a -day royal tour.Kensington Palace revealed the Duke and Duchess of Sussex were expecting their first child together on Monday, October  - less than five months after the couple married in a fairytale wedding at Windsor Castle. story: NewsPram carrying newborn baby rolls out onto busy road narrowly missing oncoming trafficHGV driver Martin Keenan captured the worrying scene unfold on his dashcam as the car in front narrowly avoided hitting the pushchair in Ashton on TamesideShareCommentsByAndrew StuartKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video terrying-moment-womans-pram-rolled-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA buggy with a baby strapped inside rolled onto a road and narrowly missed oncoming traffic after someone forgot to put the prams brake on. HGV driver Martin Keenan captured the worrying scene unfold on his dashcam as the car in front narrowly avoided hitting the pushchair as it came off the kerb. The -year-old was on his way home from work and driving down Oldham Road in Ashton, Tameside, on Tuesday afternoon when he spotted the pram coming into his vision. He told the Manchester Evening News: I saw something in the distance rolling. I didnt realise what it was until I got a bit closer. Then I realised it was the pram that rolled onto the main road.  Then I saw the lady run out of the shop. She ran to the pram with her mouth open, like Oh my god, and then got the pram off the road. If Id have stopped I would have given her a piece of my mind. story: NewsShocking details of how girl, two, was rushed to hospital after taking cocaine while escort mum was on drugs bingeThe mum, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was convicted of neglect after she continued a drink and drug binge while her daughter was left neglected at her home in October ShareByChris MatthewsAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe escort continued her boozy binge while her little girl was left home alone "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn escort whose two-year-old daughter was rushed to hospital after consuming cocaine fell asleep in the paramedics car on the way. The mum, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was convicted of neglect after she continued a drink and drug binge while her daughter was left neglected at her home in October . When a friend arrived at the mums house in Camelford, Cornwall, the following morning, she found the little girl laying on the sofa in just a nappy - unable to stand or focus before being violently sick. Following a delay in calling for an ambulance, South West Ambulance Trust paramedic Peter Rabson arrived at the scene and drove the mum and child to hospital. He described how the mum smoked cannabis in the house while he treated the toddler before sleeping most of the way to hospital, reports Cornwall Live. Speaking about the scene in the house when he arrived, Mr Rabson told Truro Crown Court he found the mum sitting on a mattress with the girl in her arms. Heavily pregnant womans nightmare night as husband suffers heart attack hours before shes due to give birthMr Rabson said of the baby: “She was drowsy but when she was spoken to and engaged with she became more alert. When I took my gaze away from her she would become glazed over and her legs couldn’t handle her weight when she stood up.” Mr Rabson explained that he spoke to an out-of-hours doctor who was suitably concerned, telling him it was “asshe’d been intoxicated with something”. Mr Rabson said: “The out-of-hours service had no clinical appointments available and the doctor was concerned so the decision was taken that I’d take her to hospital. “I had to drive tomum’s house to collect a car seat. She got out and went into the property and left the child with me, which was slightly unusual. “She came across quite unphased. After about five minutes she came back and got into the car. There was a strong smell of cannabis on her that I couldn’t smell before.” When asked about the journey to the Royal Cornwall Hospital, Mr Rabson said “we travelled for about a mile out of Camelford and then sheslept all the way to hospital”. Cot designer pleads GUILTY after baby boy chokes to death on bespoke pound bedMr Rabson also confirmed that at the time he had asked the defendantthere was a chance the child could have been exposed to any substances to which she replied no. Describing events leading up to the toddler falling ill, prosecuting barrister Philip Lee said: “In October  the defendant lived as a single parent in a terraced house. “On Friday October  the defendant left her daughter in the care of a friend and went to Plymouth to earn money as a female escort. “Later that night the defendant spoke with a friend and, as a result, went to Torquay and joined her friend there in a hotel room with her friend’s ex-partner and another man. She told police that she continued drinking at the hotel and that there were drugs there including cocaine but she didn’t take any of the cocaine.” Mr Lee outlined how the young victim had been handed over to the care of another friend before the defendant arrived back in Camelford just after midday and collected her. Mr Lee added: “Back at the defendant’s house one of the two men from Torquay was there. Toby Gill told the defendant’s friend he had been using crack in the house and during an argument the defendant told her friend she had smoked a little crack.  “The child was in the bedroom and when the friend went home she exchanged texts with the defendant. “The following morningthe friend ed to the defendant’s home. She text her and received no response then on arrival knocked on the door to which there was no answer. She looked through the letterbox and saw the child lying on the sofa only in a nappy. “She called her to sit up and then the defendant came downstairs and opened the door. It became apparent the child was unwell and her legs buckled and she was unable to stand. The defendant was upset and saying sorry. “The friend told her not to call the ambulance and that she would take her to hospital herself. Soon after the child was violently sick.” He said: “It was apparent the defendant was in a weakened and distraught state of mind and it is alleged that while the paramedic was there she began to smoke cannabis.  “He could smell a strong waft of cannabis when she got into the vehicle and then the defendant then fell asleep on the way to hospital. The defendant denied two charges of cruelty to a person under , firstly by exposing her in a manner likely to cause unnecessary suffering and another cruelty charge relating to the failure to provide her with adequate medical aid. After less than three hours of deliberation the jury found her not guilty of one charge, clearing the defendant of being responsible for the administration of the drugs, but convicted her of the second, neglect by failing to provide her child with adequate medical aid. The victim now lives with the defendants mother.

title: dads soon able breastfeed newborn
story: NewsDads may soon be able to breastfeed their newborn babies with first ever chestfeeding kitA London university student believes theyve come up with a way for dads to breastfeed their babyShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDads may soon be able to be more involved in the first few months of their babys le"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen it comes to having babies, its the woman who has to do all the hard work.Shes got to grow a human inside her for nine months, push the infant out of her body and then make milk to nourish the little one. All while her partner watches.But soon there may be a new way for the man to get more involved in the process and its all down to a kit created by a university student from London.  Marie-Claire Springham, a product design student at Central Saint Martins, is in the process of making a chestfeeding kit.The idea behind the product is for dads to be able to help mums who are struggling to breastfeed their newborns. Still in the conception stage, the kit is yet to be tested, but contains a cocktail of hormones that the man would take while his partner is pregnant, in order to grow milk ducts.The main hormone is progestin, a form of the female sex hormone progesterone, which helps to stimulate production of milk-producing glands.  This would be followed by a round of domperidone which is often given to mums who are experiencing dficulties with breastfeeding as it encourages the production of prolactin, a hormone which tells the womans body to produce milk. However there is one major possible side effect to taking the female hormones.Which is that the man could grow moobs or man boobs, up to a b cup until they stop taking the hormones.As well as the dferent hormones, the chestfeeding kit also contains a pump and a compression vest, which is very similar to a maternity bra.  Marie-Claire hopes her idea will help to stop fathers from feeling left out when raising their baby and believes the kit could be available in five years time. But its possible that the product may never see the light of day, as doctors have urged caution and warned that theres no proof men can even grow milk ducts. Theyre also not sure what impact the hormones will have on the male body and instead suggested other ways men could feel more included in the first few month of a babys le, such as changing them and helping with bath time.Speaking to The Sun Online, the -year-old student said: I was trying to create an empathy tool, something that could really help when a mum was struggling to breastfeed and could help a dad be of practical use.

title: calls for area for scrambler bikers after youths cause havoc at camperdown park and nearby
story: Calls have been made for a designated area to be introduced for scrambler bikes in a bid to tackle antisocial behaviour.There have been reports of off-road bikers causing havoc at Camperdown Park.Dash cam footage shows three riders leaving a nature trail at the popular attraction.Problems with scrambler bikes have also been reported by residents in St Mary’s and at Clatto Woods.Captain James Crawford, chairman of trustees for the Friends of Camperdown House, has called for a solution to be found to please all parties.He said: “There were similar issues in Fe with scrambler bikes coming on to the land. An agreement was reached to allow them to use the space at certain times and that has gone some way to curbing the problems.“An area the size of Camperdown is very hard to police and we certainly don’t want people riding down nature trails in the park.“It would seem to be a sensible option to try to work with the riders to find a safe area for them to use.”Strathmartine councillor Stewart Hunter said he was happy to look at finding a solution to an “old problem”.He said: “In my time as a councillor there has always been a problem with scrambler bikes.“The police do all they can butthere was a place where the riders could go it would certainly make a lot of sense.“The problem is finding a suitable location that is safe and secluded.”Fellow area councillor Ian Borthwick said the latest incident was another example of “reckless” behaviour by those involved.He added: “I will certainly bring this latest incident to the attention of the authorities.“I’ve been made aware of issues in the park in the past.”Alan Ross, convener of the city council’s community safety and public protection committee, urged anyone who witnesses antisocial behaviour involving scrambler bikes to contact the police or the community safety wardens.He added: “This type of behaviour is completely unacceptable and is a blight on our communities.”

title: george cran roles reversed as pressure now on dunfermline and allan johnston as dundee united look to gather momentum
story: With the first quarter of the season behind them, it’s fair to say it’s been a bumpy ride so far for Dundee United.Often coaches will use this point of the campaign as the first real chance to assess how things are going as they prepare to meet sides for the second time in the league.For the Tangerines, though, a report card right now can’t possibly tell the whole story with Csaba Laszlo not even lasting to this marker in charge of the team.And to judge his replacement Robbie Neilson after just two matches in charge wouldn’t be fair.However, comparing the fortunes of their next opponents Dunfermline since they met on the opening league match of the season makes for interesting reading.That’s because the atmosphere around Allan Johnston’s Pars since they finally overturned a -match winless run against the Tangerines to continue a lightning-fast start to the campaign has flipped almost completely.While the Tangerines struggled and stumbled under Csaba’s reign at the start of the season, Johnston was enjoying seeing his side inflict a - win at Tannadice to make it five wins from five games played after a % record in their Betfred Cup group.That was with an impressive  goals scored and included a deserved - win at Premiership Dundee.Now, though, Johnston faces a new man in the other dugout with intense scrutiny from fans now on him rather than his opposite number.After their perfect start to the campaign, it took Dunfermline another five matches to register a second victory in the Championship and have only racked up eight points from eight matches since.In the process they only managed six goals, conceding  and being dumped out of both the League Cup and Irn-Bru Cup on penalty shoot-outs.Going into Saturday’s game at East End Park, the Pars sit adrt of the play-off places, four points behind United in fourth place.Another poor result, after their - home defeat to Queen of the South at the weekend, will leave them well behind in the race for the top four, heaping all the pressure on Johnston and his side.And the contrast with Neilson, his United players and the atmosphere among the support is stark.After kicking off his reign with a - victory at Partick Thistle, the new gaffer led the Tangerines out for the first time at Tannadice at the weekend.Despite not managing to make it two wins from two, drawing - with Inverness CT, the players were boosted by the biggest home crowd of the campaign.The belief that Neilson can repeat the feat of promotion to the Premiership he achieved at Hearts is clear among the United support.Optimism throughout the stands has been almost completely absent over the past couple of seasons but the hope is now with former chairman Stephen Thompson having departed, and Neilson taking the reigns, good times might be on the horizon.And the ideal time to fuel that fire is now with games against sides below them in the table coming up – Dunfermline this weekend and then Queens the week after.With both the sides coming up in indferent form, points are a must to keep the good feeling flowing.Because what Dunfermline did show the last time the teams met, despite what’s happened since, is they can actually beat their bogey side United.What Neilson can’t afford now is to let the early momentum slip away, something that happened with both Ray McKinnon and, more obviously, Csaba Laszlo.Preventing that could well show the fans’ early optimism is justied come the season end.

title: jim mcintyre expected to make first dundee signing ahead of celtic clash
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is swtly set to bolster his options by adding free agent Martin Woods to his squad.The former Ross County midfielder has been without a club since leaving Partick Thistle after their relegation last season and is set to be re-united with his former gaffer.McIntyre signed Woods twice while gaffer in Dingwall, the first a month after taking charge before the -year-old had a spell down south with Shrewsbury before ing north.Woods has been training with the Dark Blues since last week and was present at last night’s - defeat to Hearts.He’s expected to become the manager’s first signing before next week’s home clash with Celtic.Woods was previously linked Dens back in the summer but the move never materialised under the reigns of then-manager Neil McCann.

title: we must avoid avoid pressing self destruct button urges dundee boss
story: Jim McIntyre praised his players’ work-rate but felt they again pressed the self-destruct button as his first home game in charge ended in defeat to Premiership leaders Hearts.Jim’s Dens Park bow got off to the worst possible start as his Dark Blues fell behind to an Oliver Bozanic free-kick after just two minutes.Twelve minutes later they were - down as Jambos skipper Steven Naismith found the back of the next.The start to the second half was even worse as Steven MacLean made it - just  seconds after the restart and put the game beyond the home team.The lapses that led to all three goals were frustrating for Jim but at least he felt able to praise some of the work put in, particularly in the first half.“The players showed plenty of character at - down, the way it’s been going recently it would be easy to just feel sorry for yourselves and just collapse but we never,” he said.“We had a real go at it in that first half and created some good opportunities ourselves. That’s the positive to take, but we need to eradicate self-destructing.“There was a bit of that and their might be a bit of pain before it gets better but it will get better, that’s for sure”Dundee squandered a great opportunity to get back in the game when Calvin Miller fired wide from the penalty spot with the score at - and Jim felt other chances went begging as well.“Hearts are a good side, but you can’t stand off teams. You’ve got to make sure you are taking the game to them as well.“I felt they did that on a number of occasions and we drove Hearts back and created opportunities. When you get those opportunities that lts the belief to go to the next level.“Obviously the penalty is the biggest chance and we have a great chance with a head as well and we should have done better at that.“The pleasing thing is we didn’t crumble and feel sorry for ourselves.”Things don’t get any easier for Jim and his players and after a free weekend, next up at Dens Park are Champions Celtic a week tonight.After that one comes what is already looking a massive clash at Motherwell on Saturday week.
